Mortals who recite it shall prolong their years and attain long life, later achieving the Way of corpse liberation.

"Mortals" refer to the common folk. Perfected Ziyang said: *"The method of the great elixir is most simple and easy; even the foolish and ignorant may practice it and ascend to sagehood."* Corpse liberation takes four forms: the first is liberation by weapon, as when Ji Kang was executed in the marketplace or Huainan met his end in prison.

The second is liberation by literary means, as when Ciqing transformed his essence into shoes or Changfang borrowed form from bamboo. The third is liberation by water or fire, as when Feng Yi drowned in the great river or Fengzi was burned in the great tree. The fourth is seated liberation: though appearing dead, the feet do not turn blue, the skin does not wrinkle, the eyes do not dim, and the limbs remain pliable at another’s touch. This is called "Refining the Form in the Great Yin," where the flesh remains uncorrupted for over a hundred years before reviving as a living person.

*The True Sayings* states: "Those who achieve corpse-liberation as immortals cannot ride the flowered canopy, mount the dragon, or ascend to the Great Ultimate; they merely avoid death." Thus, it is said that the hun-soul and spirit temporarily vanish, bypassing hell, and swiftly regain form to roam the great void. Some explain that in corpse-liberation, the bones become lustrous and light, the essence and blood remain unchanged, and if the corpse is cast into famous mountains or great rivers, after a hundred years it transforms into pearls and jade.

This scripture is subtle and wondrous, universally delivering boundless beings; all heavenly and mortal beings receive its blessings. Interpreted through the Dao, this scripture is the supreme treasure, the Golden Elixir. Its subtlety is the White Tiger, the Two Sevens. As Master Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Medicine* says: "The Two Sevens gather and assist." Through the subtle power of this scripture, when followed, it gives life to beings; when reversed, it forms the elixir. It broadly saves the sentient and universally delivers the boundless. All heavenly and mortal beings—great cultivators—are like the two weights of gold and cinnabar, or the dual substances of dragon and tiger in the golden elixir, none fail to receive its blessings. Heavenly and mortal beings employ both method and medicine, thus all receive its blessings. When the scripture’s merit is complete and the elixir’s path is perfected, how could one merely receive the grace of long life for oneself? Even ancestors widely receive the favor of transcendence.

This is treasured by Heaven and not transmitted to the lower world. This is explained through worldly methods. Master Qingyuan said: "When the perfected ascend to present their reports, they must recite this chapter in song." Heaven truly treasures and does not transmit it to the lower world. Only because later sagely rulers earnestly requested it to guard against the calamities of Jia and Shen did the sages pass it down through generations, excluding the common folk. Only the most refined scholars, offering gold and treasures as tokens of sincerity, pledging their hearts and swearing oaths to the heavens, may receive its transmission. Why? Because what people cherish most are gold and treasures. Gold is a substance of firmness and hardness; the Most High established this to make people relinquish what they love, breaking their stingy hearts, and through this offering, turn their minds toward devotion, demonstrating sincerity as firm as metal and stone. If lightly leaked or recklessly transmitted, calamity will extend to nine generations.

When serving this scripture, the Five Emperors, twenty-four Jade Boys, and twenty-four Jade Maidens attend—this is the Daoist interpretation. The scripture is the ancestral qi. The Five Emperors wondrously transform the qi of the Five Phases; the twenty-four maidens unite the inner and outer two luminaries, the true spirits and true qi, nourishing and protecting the elixir body, safeguarding those who receive the scripture to perfect the great elixir. Formerly, when Xu Jingsun refined the returning elixir, he moved the Emperor Above to dispatch five immortal boys wielding swords to descend to Jingsun, daily sparring with him, and later he achieved the Dao. Was this not to protect the body of one receiving the scripture?

A verse says:
*Heaven’s treasured scripture is not lightly passed,
Only those who receive it directly may ascend to Heaven.
What value lies in offering gold as sincerity?
This scripture’s subtlety brings boundless fortune.*

The Dao states: During the long fast of the first month, recite and chant this scripture to sever the earthly bonds of past lives’ souls and deliver them to the Southern Palace. During the long fast of the seventh month, recite and chant this scripture to attain immortality, with one’s name recorded in the heavens; the Yellow Register and White Slips erase death and inscribe life. During the long fast of the tenth month, recite and chant this scripture to secure the kingdom’s ruler, ministers, fathers and sons, stabilize the nation’s destiny, preserve Heaven’s eternal existence, and ensure the lineage of rulers continues unbroken, ever reigning as sovereigns, pacifying their lands, with the people enjoying great peace.

On the eight solar terms, recite and chant this scripture to become a Perfected One of the Nine Palaces. On one’s life-destiny day, recite and chant this scripture to purify the hun-soul and spirit, eternally preserve the myriad qi, avoid suffering, radiate light from the body, receive the attendance of the Three Realms, the Five Emperors’ welcoming, the homage of myriad spirits, with one’s name inscribed in Heaven. When merit is complete and virtue perfected, one ascends to the Upper Clarity.

Master Shangyang said: According to worldly methods, during the long fast of the first month, recite and chant this scripture. The first month is the beginning of the year, the first of the four *meng* months, the month of the Heavenly Official’s Upper Prime grand celebration. Unwavering focus is called "long," vigilant mindfulness is called "fast"—this is the long fast of the first month. Vocalizing aloud is called "recitation," continuous chanting while walking or sitting is called "chanting"—this is reciting and chanting this scripture.

Master Qingyuan said: The first month is the beginning of the four starts, when Heaven and Earth communicate and all things renew. Riding the Heavenly Official’s examination standard, the long fast and scripture recitation deliver past lives’ souls, severing the suffering of earthly bonds and delivering them to the Southern Palace. In Daoist practice, this is the month of advancing the fire and gathering the medicine, all for the purpose of beginning inner cultivation.

*The Inner Meaning* states: The first month belongs to *yin*. In elixir refinement and medicine gathering, *yin* and *shen* are the phases of rise and fall. *Yin* is the phase of yang’s arising; if one wishes to act at the *jia* hour, one must first guard at the *yin* hour, then apply at the *jia* hour. The long fast is purifying the mind; reciting the scripture is gathering qi. Purifying the mind and gathering qi is gathering the medicine. The souls of past lives are the accumulated yin qi within the body. Though yang qi arises from *zi*, one yang lies beneath five yins; by the *yin* hour, yin and yang are still intertwined, yin above and yang below, pent-up and not yet free—hence the term "earthly bonds." By the *jia* hour, through the method’s steaming, yang qi vigorously rises and ascends into the *Li* Palace. Is this not severing earthly bonds and delivering to the Southern Palace? Thus, the scripture’s references to the Vermilion Palace, the Upper Palace of Southern Prosperity, Vermilion Mound, or Southern Palace all denote the *Li* Palace.

The *Li* Palace corresponds to the *Kan* position, hence Master Zhang’s saying: "Take the solid center from the *Kan* position and refine the yin within the *Li* Palace’s belly." By observing the long fast in the seventh month and reciting this scripture, one attains immortality. The seventh month belongs to *shen*, a time when yang lies concealed. To practice at the *geng* hour, one first guards at the *shen* hour; by the *geng* hour, mercury is set in motion to merge with lead, forming the treasure within the crucible—this is also called "gathering the medicine" or "casting the crucible." As yang qi grows daily stronger, yin qi wanes. Pure yin is a ghost; pure yang, an immortal. When yang qi is robust, one gradually attains immortality. With practice complete and qi full, the spirit transforms and the embryo is released—thus the true person emerges, hence "attaining immortality in body." Those who achieve the Dao have their names stricken from the registers of death in Fengdu and inscribed in the ledgers of immortality, receiving charts and registers, thereby ascending. Thus it is said: "The heavens record names on yellow registers and white tablets, erasing death to grant life."

In the tenth month, observe the long fast and recite this scripture. The *Inner Meaning* states: "When the medicine is fully gathered and the crucible is cast to perfection, enter the chamber in the tenth month to harmonize spirit and qi. Beginning fifteen days before the winter solstice, fast and store the spirit within the kidneys—this is called 'fortifying the numinous root.' Thus, the root and origin are established, and spirit and qi arise together. The body is like a nation: the spirit is its lord, qi its minister. When spirit is full and qi abundant, the hundred bones are all ordered. The elixir is completed, the form is shed, and one attains long life and enduring vision. Bone and flesh ascend together, form and spirit unite in subtlety—just as the scripture declares."

On the days of the eight nodes, recite this scripture to become a True Person of the Nine Palaces. The eight nodes correspond to the eight trigrams. Entering the chamber to circulate the talisman and advance the fire, take the *zi* hour of the winter solstice as the starting point, storing the spirit in the kidneys. As the yang fire moves, the spirit follows in its wake. The kidneys are the root; the spirit chamber, the girdle. From root to girdle, root and girdle move in concert, forming the embryo and ripening the fruit. One cycle encompasses three hours: from *zi* to *chou*, from *chou* to *yin*, metal and fire press forward, returning to the spirit chamber, and the golden elixir gradually coalesces. This corresponds to the winter solstice and the beginning of spring, nodes governed by the *Kan* and *Gen* trigrams. By the *mao* hour, one bathes; by the *chen* hour, the fire advances. By *si*, metal and fire press forward, returning to the sea of marrow. This corresponds to the spring equinox and the beginning of summer, nodes governed by the *Zhen* and *Xun* trigrams. When the yang fire reaches its peak, at the *wu* hour, the talisman is circulated. From *wei* to *shen*, metal and water propel the movement, entering the chamber via the magpie bridge at the double pass, enclosing and securing the mysterious pearl. This corresponds to the summer solstice and the beginning of autumn, nodes governed by the *Li* and *Kun* trigrams. By the *you* hour, one bathes; by *xu* and *hai*, the talisman is circulated, and true qi returns to its source, as one yang revives. This corresponds to the autumn equinox and the beginning of winter, nodes governed by the *Dui* and *Qian* trigrams. The cycle repeats endlessly, condensing a year’s work into a single day to correspond with the eight nodes. All applications of yang fire and yin talismans return to the central palace to nurture the sacred embryo. After ten months, when qi is full and the treasure crucible’s work is complete, the embryo is released and the spirit transforms—this is the True Person.

The eight trigrams are arrayed in a circle, solid without and hollow within, with the elixir body residing at the center. The *Book of Changes* says: "The eight trigrams are arrayed, and their images lie within." This is why one becomes a True Person of the Nine Palaces. In worldly custom, the days of the eight nodes are when the Great Unity’s Controller of Destiny, along with various officials, records the merits, transgressions, blessings, and faults of mortals. Merits are rewarded; faults, punished. On these days, reciting the scripture allows one to seize the opportunity for commendation and become a True Person of the Nine Palaces.

On one’s life-destiny day, recite this scripture to purify the hun-spirits and rectify the myriad qi, ensuring their enduring presence. The human body possesses three hun-spirits: one resides in the celestial offices, belonging to one’s natal constellation; one dwells in the earthly prison; and one abides within the body. The seven po-spirits constantly inhabit the body. The seven po-spirits cause confusion and indulgence, while the three hun-spirits delight in goodness. On one’s life-destiny day, the hun-spirits descend into the body to join the corpse, circulating in unbroken union. Thus, the living person remains peaceful, and calamities and illnesses do not arise. On this day, by purifying the body, one unites hun and po. The hun belongs to yang; the po, to yin. When yin and yang harmonize, the Dao’s qi descends within, the root of life is fortified, and the body is at peace.

If one’s form is befuddled by wine and lust, the hun-spirit, upon appearing, retreats seven paces from the body and cannot unite. Polluted and defiled, the hun departs. The seven po-spirits, unable to unite with the hun, grow ever more dominant, stirring and indulging their desires. If one is befuddled thrice and the hun cannot unite with the po, yang wanes while yin waxes, and the seven po-spirits commune with yin ghosts, fostering only lewd thoughts. The seven po-spirits each have names: Corpse Dog, Crouching Corpse, Sparrow Yin, Swallowing Thief, Flying Poison, Removing Filth, and Fetid Lung. Corpse Dog governs greed; Crouching Corpse, gluttony; Sparrow Yin, lust; Swallowing Thief, theft; Flying Poison, delusion; Removing Filth, corruption of goodness; and Fetid Lung, all afflictions. Because they are unwholesome, their names are likewise vile. If one’s thoughts are impure, they are drawn into depravity—indulging in wine and lust, wandering in dreams among evils, engaging in filthy and defiled conduct, lost in confusion and excessive sleep, depleting essence and exhausting spirit, dissipating qi and multiplying illness, vexing and disturbing until death—while they, by contrast, find ease.

When on one’s life-destiny day one diligently cultivates goodness, recites scriptures, and practices the Dao without weariness, advancing without retreat, so that one’s virtuous deeds reach heaven—then, as the scripture promises, when merit is complete and virtue perfected, one ascends in flight. In Master Xu’s *Method of the Numinous Treasure Pure Brightness Scripture for Delivering Humanity*, there are ten "Do Nots Forget." The most essential is "Do not forget firmness and purity." Firmness means having resolve and not indulging in lewdness; purity means maintaining precepts and not craving food and drink. Avoiding lewdness prevents harm to body and spirit; abstaining from gluttony prevents the taking of lives.

Thus, those who indulge in wine and lust while reciting scriptures and discoursing on the Dao commit the gravest transgression. These are but worldly interpretations of the Dharma. Yet if one speaks of the application of the Dao, there lies a wondrous principle.

The day of one’s life-destiny is the day of gathering the medicine and entering the chamber; it is the day of returning to the origin and reverting to the root; it is the day of returning to the foundation and restoring life. Therefore, within a year, there is only this one day; within this day, only one hour; within this hour, merely two *ke*. This is the method of gathering the clan. One condenses the seventy-two seasonal nodes into a single day, clusters the thirty-six thousand breaths of primordial qi into one hour—each hour encompassing six nodes, yet only two are used for reciting scriptures and refining the elixir. Thus, within that hour, four nodes remain, reserved for other wondrous applications, transmitted only in secret teachings. Such is the day of one’s life-destiny.

Master Peng said: At first, there is no form or substance, as in the primordial chaos of *hongmeng*. Once the fire is kindled and the talismans are activated, the first year of cultivation begins to flourish—this is the day of one’s life-destiny, the inception of receiving qi. The *Cantong Qi* states: "At the capping and marriage, qi intertwines; in the first year, the sprout flourishes." The *Inner Meaning* says: "When the fire’s timing is complete, the way of shedding the mortal coil and transforming the spirit is achieved." The sacred embryo resides within the sea of marrow, with a cycle of sixty days; the life-destiny completes one revolution to match the number of the celestial cycle. Suddenly, like the crack of thunder, the Gate of Heaven splits open, the sacred embryo emerges, the mortal husk is shed, and one becomes an immortal—attaining eternal life. The Demon Kings bear witness, the hosts of heaven welcome, merit is fulfilled, virtue is exalted, and ascension awaits.

Li Changling said: "Merit is the practice of daily conduct; virtue is the renewal of each day." If one is as earnest as a farmer awaiting the harvest, as diligent as a merchant amassing wealth—accumulating virtue today, piling merit tomorrow—then the three hundred virtues of an Earth Immortal may be completed in a single year, and the one thousand three hundred virtues of a Heavenly Immortal in four years. Yet though many begin the practice, most falter midway, for their resolve is not steadfast.

The Purple Void Primordial Sovereign said: Master Fu, from youth, loved the Dao. He entered a stone chamber on Mount Jiao for seven years, where he suddenly encountered the Supreme Ultimate Perfected One, who bestowed upon him a wooden drill and bade him bore through a millstone. The master warned: "When the stone is pierced, I shall deliver you." The stone was over five feet thick, yet Fu drilled without cease. After forty-seven years, the stone was suddenly pierced through, and the Supreme Ultimate Perfected One indeed came to deliver him. Such was the utmost firmness of his resolve—how much more so for those who recite scriptures and practice the Dao with diligence!

A hymn says:
*For three months, maintain the fast and chant this scripture,*
*The host of heaven’s sages shall inscribe your name.*
*Though men know the day of life-destiny for chanting scriptures,*
*In daily practice, they act in folly.*

The Dao teaches: On the day of practicing the Dao, one must bathe in fragrant waters, observe abstinence, enter the chamber, face east, and knock the teeth thirty-two times to ascend to the thirty-two heavens. Bow thirty-two times in the heart. Close the eyes and meditate, sitting amidst clouds of blue, yellow, and white qi, inwardly and outwardly shrouded in mist. Green Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, Dark Warrior, Lion, and White Crane array themselves to left and right. Sun and moon shine brightly, illuminating the chamber; a radiant halo appears above the head, its light suffusing the ten directions—all must be vividly perceived.

The secret incantation says:
*Tanluo Yuluo, Fuwu Sutuo.*
*Great Thoroughfare, Supreme Ultimate,*
*Yin Heart—no wine, no lust,*
*Change garments, burn incense,*
*Recite scriptures, practice goodness,*
*Sit without sleep, Yang envelops Harmony.*
*Exiting existence, entering non-existence,*
*Entering life, exiting death.*
*Ghosts and spirits cannot fathom,*
*Transformations arise naturally.*
*Primordial Hunqi, Mystery within Mystery.*
*Above, it reaches the End; below, it penetrates the Great Abyss.*
*Recite once, and chronic illness heals itself.*
*Refine the hun-soul, bathe the po-soul,*
*True Yang is preserved whole.*
*Observe abstinence, perform rites, recite—*
*Ten thousand repetitions, and one ascends as an immortal.*
*This supreme secret incantation grants an enduring mandate.*
*Recite the heart incantation again:*
*Tanluo reveals the light.*
*Jade Clarity, Supreme Pole,*
*Brahma qi suffuses and steams.*
*Dispense the numinous, spread the qi,*
*Bestow and infuse the body.*
*Form and spirit both wondrous,*
*Merge with the Dao and become true.*
*This servant attains the Dao,*
*Seven ancestors ascend as immortals.*
*Like golden statutes, they descend,*
*Commanding the ten thousand spirits.*
*Hasten! As the Law of the Primordial Mystery and the Mystic Capital decrees.*

The Most High Primordial Supreme Lord of the Dao summons from this servant’s body the Three and Five Merit Officers, the Attendant Envoys of the Left and Right, the Incense-Bearing Golden Youths, the Jade Maidens who transmit words, the Five Emperors’ Direct Talismans, and the Direct-Day Incense Officers—thirty-two each. They are to relay the words spoken today: a day of auspicious celebration, a hall of purity and fasting, the cultivation of this supreme scripture, the deliverance of boundless beings, the turning of the scriptures to receive rebirth. May the prayers ascend directly to the Most High Primordial Lord of the Thirty-Two Heavens before the august throne.

Afterward, draw qi thirty-two times and recite the scriptures facing east.

Master Shangyang said: This scripture truly reveals the essence of cultivation and demonstrates the truth of the ancestral qi. Thus, it speaks of "the day of practicing the Dao" rather than "the day of reciting scriptures," for one must know: the scripture is the elixir, the elixir is the Dao, and the Dao is the scripture. Without the Dao, the scripture does not emerge; without the scripture, the elixir does not emerge; without the elixir, the Dao is not accomplished. This is an immutable principle, with no alternative path. Here, the application of the Dao and the worldly Dharma are expounded together.

There are two kinds of practicing the Dao: internal and external. First, the external practice: bathing, observing abstinence, solemnly arranging the altar, burning incense, reciting scriptures, pacing the void, and offering morning and evening praises—this is the external practice of the Dao.

The Azure Primordial Sovereign of the Eastern Sea said: Using five-fragrance water and reciting incantations to wash the body is the great external bathing in Brahma qi, which circulates through the ten directions. Internally, it harmonizes the five qi and unites the hundred spirits—this is internal bathing.

Abstinence does not merely mean refraining from meat and impurity; one must first sever lustful desires. Only then can the heart be aligned to avert misfortune, and the nature be restrained to dispel calamity.

Entering the chamber means entering stillness, free from worldly dust, with body and mind wholly concentrated—thus may one commune with the divine spirits. The east is the direction of long life, where one summons the qi of generation; the method of knocking the teeth: the left is the Heavenly Bell, the right the Heavenly Chime, to summon the immortals. The center is the Heavenly Drum, used to offer morning praises to the Most High. Heart-bowing means the body remains unmoving while the mind is wholly intent on reverence. Closing the eyes means withdrawing vision to gaze inward, so that qi settles into profound stillness.

Azure is the qi of the Mysterious One, yellow the qi of the Primordial One, white the qi of the Original One. The significance of these three colors is drawn from the Three Pure Ones. Sitting in meditation upon them, the divine numina will naturally appear. Inner visions and outer realms merge in misty oneness.

Next, visualize the Azure Dragon emerging from the liver and residing on the left; the White Tiger emerging from the lungs and residing on the right; the Vermilion Bird emerging from the heart and residing in front; the Dark Warrior emerging from the kidneys and residing behind. Visualize six lions and six cranes emerging from the six bowels, dividing left and right.

The left eye transforms into the solar orb, radiating nine layers of purple-red light; the right eye transforms into the lunar orb, radiating seven layers of yellow-white light. These orbs stand three feet from the body, their brilliance resplendent, shining into the nose, passing through the back of the brain, entering the Golden Flower Palace, and coalescing into a wheel of light as large as a chariot wheel. The three colors—azure, yellow, and white—intermingle within it, forming the Nine-Colored Round Image. With this radiance, illuminate the ten directions, then recite the preceding esoteric incantation. "Esoteric" means not vocalizing aloud. After the incantation, perform the closing announcement as before.

Once the closing announcement is complete, face east and sit upright. Visualize the four spirit-beasts and other gods emerging from within the body, arrayed before you to listen to the Dharma and hear the scriptures. Then recite aloud with resonant clarity, without straying thoughts, idle conversation, or interrupting the scriptural recitation. As if before a sovereign or father, allow no trace of negligence—strive to achieve thorough resonance with Heaven. This is the external practice of the Dao, the natural course of worldly methods.

If one practices the internal Dao, however, it becomes the application of the Dao. The matter is entirely distinct—why? When ordinary people read scriptures, they merely read through them without realizing that the scripture itself is a great practice, teaching one to follow the Dao within it. Thus, it is called the day of practicing the Dao, not the day of reading scriptures. In refining the internal elixir, there is the work of entering the chamber and applying effort, hence it is called entering the chamber facing east, not ascending the altar. Ascending the hall refers to the teachings of refining the returning elixir.

Now, the scripture is reverence. The Heavenly Worthy expounds the scriptures to enable the foolish to know where to return. Reverence inclines the heart toward goodness, prevents wrongdoing, and through storing spirit and nurturing qi, one may avoid disaster. If one recites without bathing, observing abstinence, or changing garments before entering the chamber, one will instead invite misfortune and condemnation. Yet if a superior person or perfected being practices the Dao within the scripture, it is called the day of practicing the Dao. The scripture is the Dao, and the Dao is the elixir—only in refining the elixir does the matter of entering the chamber arise, hence it is called entering the chamber facing east.

In refining the returning elixir, one must first refine the self and stabilize the mind, hence the term "bathing." A person of the Dao first severs desires, hence the term "abstinence." The foolish, unaware of this, merely recite loudly without understanding. What is practicing the Dao? It is refining the returning elixir. What is the returning elixir? It must be taught by a master. Thus, the Perfected One of Pure Yang said: "Without a master’s guidance, this matter is difficult to know." Laozi said: "I am not a sage; I obtained this through learning." Therefore, to learn the elixir, one must first seek a master and not recklessly speculate.

Having received the master’s transmission, one must first refine the self. What is refining the self? It is eliminating desires and nurturing essence and qi. Thus, Pure Yang said: "First refine the self and await the time." Having refined the self, one must find a fellow practitioner to serve as external protection. Liu Haichan said: "This matter is no ordinary matter; seeking a person, one has not yet found the right person." Chen Ninwan said: "Without like-minded companions to guide one, when awakened, one may fear the fire-timing in the crucible is amiss."

Having found a companion, first seek the furnace and cauldron. The *Awakening to Reality* states: "First take Qian and Kun as the furnace and vessel; next, gather the Crow and Hare as the medicine to refine." Having obtained the furnace and cauldron, then select the day. What is selecting the day? The Perfected One of Purple Yang said: "When lead encounters the birth of Gui, one must swiftly gather it." He also said: "When the sweet dew descends, Heaven and Earth unite." This is the meaning.

Having obtained the day, one must also obtain the hour. Then proceed with the hexagram qi. Thus, the *Awakening to Reality* says: "Take the solid center of the Kan position and transform the yin within the Li palace." Therefore, knocking the teeth thirty-two times and bowing thirty-two times corresponds to the sixty-four hexagrams. Closing the eyes in still contemplation—Master Boyang said: "The three treasures—ears, eyes, and mouth—must be closed and not allowed to leak." The Perfected One dives into the deep abyss, floating and roaming while guarding the compass within.

Sitting amidst the azure, yellow, and white clouds of qi—my master Yuanduzi said: "The primordial qi of the prior Heaven comes from the realm of emptiness and non-being. Azure qi is mercury, white qi is lead, and yellow qi is earth. Before mercury and lead unite, they rely on earth to combine them." The *Preface by Purple Yang* states: "Pursue the two qi along the Yellow Path, unite the three natures in the palace of non-being, gather the five phases, harmonize the four images. When the dragon intones and the tiger roars, husband and wife follow in succession, then one knows the inner and outer merge in misty oneness, the four beasts arrayed, the sun and moon shining brightly, illuminating the chamber within. A wheel of light appears above the nape—so vividly clear."

The esoteric incantation refers to the great sound that is soundless. This is called practicing the Dao, this is called reciting scriptures, this is called the inner and outer two visions. Once the elixir is refined, then perform the closing announcement, and the hun and po within the body will all transform into spirits.

A hymn says:
The work of entering the chamber severs deluded emotions,
Reciting scriptures and practicing the Dao—begin cultivation early.
It is said that the Jade Maiden first makes the announcement,
Then one ascends through the thirty-two heavens in sequence.

The *Supreme Esoteric Commentary on the Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Beginning’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity, First Scroll* concludes.

*The Supreme Esoteric Commentary on the Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Beginning’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity from the Numinous Treasure of the Cavernous Mystery, Middle Scroll*
Commentary by Chen Guanwu of Shangyang

Shangyangzi states: "Scripture" is the Dao, and it is reverence. The Dao is to be honored in practice, and reverence is to be upheld without lapse. The world knows what to revere: the Three Treasures. These Three Treasures are indeed the essence of the wondrous Dao. Explained through the Dao’s function, they are called the Three Treasures within the body; explained through worldly dharma, they are called the Three Treasures within the teachings. Regarding the Three Treasures within the body, there are two matters. Regarding the Three Treasures within the teachings, there are two interpretations.

Here, the Three Treasures within the teachings are the Dao, the scriptures, and the master. There are two interpretations: the present canon and the ancient canon. The Dao is the primordial qi of the Mysterious Unity of Primordial Beginning, which gives birth to heaven, earth, and all beings—this is the Treasure of the Dao. The scriptures are the teachings expounded by the Jade Dawn Dao Lord from the Dao of the Mysterious Unity of Primordial Beginning, serving as the ladder and raft for all ages—this is the Treasure of the Scriptures. The master is Lord Lao, who descended to bestow the scriptures and registers upon Heavenly Master Zhang, transmitting the teachings through the world—this is the Treasure of the Master. The origin and transmission of the teachings truly follow the Heavenly Master, yet there are also two interpretations. Thus, the Three Treasures of the earlier canon are called the present canon, while those of the later canon are called the ancient canon, and their designations differ.

This is the worldly method of transforming customs. If speaking of the Dao’s function, then it is the Three Treasures within the body, which also comprise two matters. The essence of the Primordial Beginning’s Mysterious Unity and utmost perfection is called the Heavenly Treasure, also known as the Treasure of the Dao. The precelestial qi of the Golden Liquor of Supreme Clarity is called the Numinous Treasure, also known as the Treasure of the Scriptures. The spirit of the Primal Chaos and the Ultimateless is called the Spirit Treasure, also known as the Dharma Treasure. Without these Three Treasures within the body, one cannot return the elixir, cannot become a buddha, cannot attain immortality. The *Great Golden Book of the Three Treasures* states that the Heavenly Treasure, Numinous Treasure, and Spirit Treasure all transform through qi—these are also the Three Treasures within the body.

If discussing the Dao of the golden liquor and returning the elixir, then the Three Treasures within the body have two further interpretations: spirit, qi, and essence are the inner Three Treasures, while the ears, eyes, and mouth are the outer Three Treasures. If one honors the outer Three Treasures and does not act recklessly, then the inner Three Treasures will coalesce to form the returned elixir and nurture the fetal immortal. Thus, the true writs and precious talismans, the dragon scripts and phoenix seals, the jade tablets and golden books, the profound classics of the Three Caverns, and the thirty-six sections of eighteen thousand chapters all emerge from the Three Treasures—these are called scriptures. Therefore, scripture is the elixir, the primordial qi of the precelestial.

This *Scripture of Limitless Salvation* was expounded by the Jade Dawn Dao Lord from the Dao of Primordial Beginning and transmitted to the Perfected of Mysterious Unity. The Perfected of Mysterious Unity transmitted it to the Heavenly Perfected August Person, who, following the Dao Lord’s transmission, inscribed it into scripture. Thus, each chapter begins with the words of the Dao, except for this chapter and the two chapters of the *Jade Calendar*, where the August Person directly inscribed the Dao of Primordial Beginning. Yet all derive from the Dao Lord’s transmission. Today, some mistakenly regard chapters with the words of the Dao as prefaces and those without as the scripture itself. To recite only the two chapters while omitting the preceding scripture is even more erroneous.

The title *Supreme Wondrous Scripture of the Numinous Treasure of the Cavernous Mystery’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity* was bestowed by the August Person. This title, *Supreme Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Beginning’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity*, was bestowed by the Dao Lord. Though the origins and transmissions of the scriptures differ, all scriptures emerge from the Dao Lord, and thus the Dao Lord is the Treasure of the Scriptures. The scriptures embody the Dao in practice, and the Dao functions through the scriptures. If discussing the golden liquor and returning the elixir, then the scriptures precede the elixir in practice, and the elixir follows the scriptures in function. Borrowing the scriptures to represent the elixir, it is called the *Precelestial Supreme Numinous Treasure Ninefold Return of the Golden Elixir*. Borrowing the Dao to expound the scriptures, it is called the *Supreme Wondrous Scripture of Primordial Beginning’s Limitless Salvation of Humanity*.

A hymn says:
The spirit, qi, and essence of Primordial Beginning’s precelestial,
Its wondrous workings boundless, most numinous.
To save others and oneself, one must be saved by others—
The supreme elixir’s method is the wondrous scripture.

The primordial Cavernous Mystery, the original chapter of the Numinous Treasure,
The supreme wondrous beginning, ten cycles of salvation,
A hundred demons concealed in rhyme, naturally converging and parting,
The crimson writ of the Chaotic Abyss—
The Ultimateless, the Supreme Perfected, the Primordial Beginning’s kalpas,
Giving birth to all heavens, illuminating the Three Luminaries,
This is the root of heaven.
Above, there is no further ancestor; only the Dao is the body.
The five writs unfold and expand, universally planting numinous spirits.
Without writ, there is no radiance; without writ, there is no illumination;
Without writ, there is no establishment; without writ, there is no completion;
Without writ, there is no salvation; without writ, there is no birth—
This is the Heaven within the Great Brahmā Heaven,
The Jade Capital of Yu Luo, the Supreme Capital of the Jade Mountain.
Utmost above the utmost, the Great Canopy of Jade Clarity.
Vast kalpas stretch into the distance, as if absent, as if present.
The Three Flowers part, the wondrous court of Great Existence.
Golden towers and jade chambers, the pure expanse of the forest of principles.
The great circulation of Brahmā qi revolves through the ten directions.
Within it are the spirits who save humanity, the deathless gods,
Within it is the Lord of Longevity of the Southern Culmen,
Within it is the Great God Sima who saves the world,
Within it is the Venerable Han Jun who cherishes life,
Within it are the exalted gods of the Southern Supreme who govern destiny, record deeds, extend life, increase years, and save from calamity—
They turn back bones and revive the dead, boundlessly saving humanity.

Today, the collation is recorded. All heavens descend in attendance.

The Master of Supreme Yang says: This chapter is wholly the functioning of the Dao.
The Primordial Beginning—before the Great Ultimate divided—was the ancestral qi of prior heaven.
The Cavernous Mystery encompasses the three caverns’ profound secrets, the true source of the myriad methods.
The original chapter of the Numinous Treasure is essence, being, substance, the response of life, the root of the mysterious.
*Laozi* says: There is a thing, chaotically formed, born before heaven and earth.
Thus it can generate things and generate humans.
The wondrous chief of the highest grade is life, non-being, function, the response of essence, the gate of the female.
The Perfected of Purple Yang says: The *White Tiger’s Chief Scripture* and the *True Scripture of Divine Water from the Flowery Pond* are supreme treasures, for they can generate buddhas and generate immortals.
“Return” means to revert, to restore.
In scripture it is called “delivering people ten times”; in alchemy it is called “the ninefold return of golden elixir.”
This scripture stands as the crown of the Three Caverns precisely because of the word “deliver.”
To seek immortality or buddhahood, one must first understand the word “deliver,” only then can one restore this primordial yang true qi to congeal the returning elixir.
The hundred demons conceal their rhymes: the six roots entering perception, the three hun and seven po, the three divisions and eight scenes, the twenty-four spirits—those who do not know how to practice the Dao are all confounded by them, their mind-monarch led astray into the realm of desire, hence called the hundred demons.
Now that one refines the great elixir, the hundred demons are subdued, no longer vexing or testing; separation and union occur naturally.
For although the Way of the returning elixir is called “having action,” it is not forced action.
Every separation and union arises from the natural workings of creation.
*The Awakening to Reality* says: When the two things meet, essence and life unite; where the five phases are complete, tiger and dragon coil—this is it.
The *Crimson Text of Primal Chaos* is the original true nature, the indestructible primordial spirit.
The Perfected of Azure Prime says: The primordial is the root of the myriad things, established at the head of the great image, operating endlessly.
The beginning is the inception of the vague and indistinct, existing before the myriad transformations, uniquely honored and ever-changing.
The Cavernous Mystery is the profound vision of the One, transforming and delivering heaven and humanity.
The Numinous Treasure: in heaven it is numinous, in the world it is treasure.
The original chapter contains the foundation of cultivating truth and uniting with the Dao.
The highest grade alone attains the mysterious, expounding teachings with expedient means.
The wondrous chief is the chief of all wonders, the source of the myriad methods.
Heaven and earth are empty and wondrous yet clear; yin and yang share the same wonder yet are pure.
Sun and moon contain wonder and shine; the five phases unite in wonder and are refined.
The myriad things are all wondrous and true.
*The Inner Meaning* says: The wondrous chief of the highest grade is the golden liquid returning elixir, the crown of the supreme wondrous Dao.
“Delivering people ten times” is the work of ten months, delivering the world to become immortals.
“The hundred demons conceal their rhymes” is another name for the elixir.
“Separation and union occur naturally” compares the interval between metal and wood, which can again merge; water and fire, which oppose each other, can again achieve harmony—naturally completing creation.
The *Crimson Text of Primal Chaos* is the original source of the myriad things, the true nature of all beings.
The ancestor of the one qi, the ancestor revered by the myriad spirits.
*The Scripture of Western Ascent* says: The empty and non-being generates the natural; the natural completes the great Dao.
As for the Dao, it is formless and without substance, the one qi of prior heaven that transforms and generates the myriad things, the foundation of heaven and earth’s creation.
Those who refine the golden elixir embody the workings of creation through emptiness and naturalness.
The true one qi of prior heaven is called “empty qi.”
The golden womb, born of the golden mother, serves as the foundation of the elixir.
This qi, before father and mother united, shared the same body with chaos, hence called “primal chaos.”
After father and mother joined in essence, this qi responded and attached itself, called “yang essence.”
It is likened to silver ore, named “original spirit,” stored in the Palace of Earth, thus called “nature,” the original face.
Before birth it is called “yin metal”; after birth it is called “yang lead,” the mother of the five metals.
*The Kinship of the Three* says: Directly pointing to the spirit-root of heaven and earth, taking it as the ancestor of medicine; clearly showing the holy mother of yin and yang, using it as the foundation of the elixir.
Before heaven and earth’s chaos, this qi congealed into jade characters, hence called “crimson text.”
It is the supreme, unsurpassable, most true and wondrous Dao, thus called the “true of the non-being and non-non-being.”
In the primordial kalpa of the Primordial Beginning, the primordial qi of the various heavens was generated.
The beginning qi of the ancestral kalpa initially divided into three qi, generating the Three Heavens: the Heaven of Pure Tenuity, the Heaven of Yu Remainder, and the Heaven of Great Crimson.
The qi of the Three Heavens further divided into nine qi, generating the Nine Heavens: the Heaven of Beginning Azure, the Heaven of Azure Prime, the Heaven of Beginning Cinnabar, the Heaven of Great Cinnabar, the Heaven of Beginning Simplicity, the Heaven of Great Simplicity, the Heaven of Beginning Mystery, the Heaven of Great Mystery, and the Heaven of Azure Tenuity.
The Brahmā qi of the Nine Heavens further divided to generate the Nine Firmaments and Nine Heavens: the Heaven of Great Firmament Radiant Flowing Light and Pure Scenery, the Heaven of Azure Firmament Primordial True Treasure Radiance, the Heaven of Azure Firmament General Life Opening Spirit and Transmitting Dao, the Heaven of Crimson Firmament Great Peace Response and Transformation Dao Lord, the Heaven of Cinnabar Firmament Central Culmen Supreme Wondrous Empty Transformation, the Heaven of Jade Firmament Luminous Prime Majestic Virtue Shining Crystal, the Heaven of Jade Firmament Flying Azure Prime Pass Transmitting Salvation, the Heaven of Purple Firmament Conjoined Scenery Double Gates Transformation Body, and the Heaven of Divine Firmament Jade Purity Wondrous Scenery Great Existence.
The Brahmā qi of the Nine Firmaments further divided to generate the Nine Heavens below, namely the Nine Heavens of Spirit Generation:
1. The Heaven of Southern Fragrance Immeasurable Abundance;
2. The Heaven of Northwest Meditation Goodness Immeasurable Longevity;
3. The Heaven of Eastern Brahmā Surveillance Prolonged Extension;
4. The Heaven of Southwest Serene Constellation Tuṣita;
5. The Heaven of Southeast Pāramitā Secret Joyous Non-Pride;
6. The Heaven of Northern Cavernous Prime Transformation Response Sound;
7. The Heaven of Western Numinous Transformation Brahmā Assistance;
8. The Heaven of Northeast Lofty Emptiness Pure Brightness;
9. The Heaven of Central Non-Thought Non-Knot Non-Attachment.
Below these, the Thirty-Six Heavens of Great Existence, Jade Purity, and Supreme Purity were generated, and below them the Four Heavens of Seed People.
One million three hundred fifty-eight thousand li below the Heavens of Seed People lie the Four Heavens of the Formless Realm.

Beneath the Formless Realm, at a distance of three hundred sixty thousand *li*, lie the Eighteen Heavens of the Form Realm. Within the Form Realm are six Heavens of Light Dust, six Heavens of Fine Dust, and six Heavens of Coarse Dust.

Below the Form Realm, at a distance of three hundred thousand *li*, lie the Six Heavens of the Desire Realm. Beneath the Desire Realm, five hundred twenty billion ten-thousand *li* distant, five hundred million heavens are transformed and generated, along with the Eight Round Worlds.

Above the Four Heavens of Seed People, the sun, moon, and stars are arrayed, governing and sustaining the myriad things—hence called the Three Luminaries of Illumination.

Human birth follows a similar pattern. Father’s essence and mother’s blood gather within the mother’s womb. Before essence and blood congeal, they resemble a pearl or dewdrop; after congealing, the fivefold form takes shape: the head and the four limbs. In males, the left kidney forms first, followed by the right Gate of Life. In females, the reverse occurs. The root of inherent nature continues the lineage between the two kidneys, and the wondrously transforming *qi* naturally arises. Next, the divine waters of the two pupils form above, followed by the generation of the five viscera, six bowels, nine orifices, hundred vessels, sinews, bones, teeth, and hair. When *qi* is sufficient and the form is complete as metal, the fetus emerges from the womb.

Thus, Lord Lao said: "Heaven and Earth unite their essence; yin and yang spread and transform. In the first month, it is the embryo—essence and blood congeal. In the second month, it is the fetus—form begins to take shape. In the third month, the yang spirit becomes the Three Hun, moving to give life. In the fourth month, the yin numen becomes the Seven Po, still to stabilize the form. In the fifth month, the Five Agents divide into the five viscera to settle the spirit. In the sixth month, the Six Pitches determine the six bowels to nourish the numen. In the seventh month, the Seven Essences open the seven orifices to convey radiance. In the eighth month, the Eightfold Splendor of the spirit is complete, descending with true numen. In the ninth month, palaces and chambers are arrayed to secure essence. In the tenth month, *qi* is sufficient, and the myriad images are complete."

Thus, when spirit spreads and *qi* fills the thirty-six thousand joints, the root-source and original beginning simultaneously generate the spirit. This is the transformation and generation of the myriad heavens, the Three Luminaries of Illumination—this is the Heavenly Root.

The *Fundamental Scripture* states: "Only when the Dao attains three is it complete; thus, three unite to form virtue. If the Dao does not reach three, nothing can be accomplished." Internally, this refers to lead, mercury, and cinnabar. Directly pointing to the matter, it is our true nature, the wondrous transformations of daily use, and the union of yin and yang *qi* to form three. Above, there is no further ancestor—only the Dao is the body.

The *Scripture of Lord Lao’s Transformation of the Barbarians* states: "The Dao is the primordial *qi* of emptiness and nothingness. Heaven and Earth follow it to generate the myriad things, which rely upon it for form—all are the wondrous transformations of the ancestral *qi*. In the Dao, this is called the Golden Elixir; thus, it is said, 'Above, there is no further ancestor—only the Dao is the body.'"

The Five Scripts open and expand, universally planting the divine numen. In the Elixir, the One *Qi* returns and transforms to generate the Five Agents; when the Five Agents are complete, the Golden Embryo forms. In the scriptures, the Jade Characters emerge and coalesce into the Red Script; when the Five Scripts are complete, they plant the divine numen.

The Five Agents are lead, mercury, cinnabar, silver, and earth. Heaven One generates water, and within Kan (☵) lies lead. Earth Two generates fire, and within Li (☲) cinnabar is produced. Heaven Three generates wood, and within Zhen (☳) the dragon governs mercury. Earth Four generates metal, and within Dui (☱) the tiger embodies silver. Heaven Five generates earth, and within the Central Palace the Elixir coalesces.

The Dao is not illuminated without these; the scriptures are not clarified without these; the body is not established without these; the Elixir is not completed without these; *qi* is not transcended without these; the medicine is not generated without these—this is the Heaven within the Great Brahmā Heaven. The Great Brahmā is the primordial *qi* congealed, with the Five Agents fully prepared. The Heaven within Heaven means there is a body within the body.

Yu Luo Xiao Terrace is the region of the brain. Jade Mountain’s Upper Capital is the Muddy Pellet. The Utmost Supreme is the Great Canopy of Jade Purity and Supreme Mystery above the Muddy Pellet. Within the Supreme Mystery lies a secret mechanism called the High Ascent of Sun and Moon—the essential method for spirit transformation and shedding the embryo.

The *Yellow Court Scripture* states: "Ascending the sun and moon, I attain the Dao above, and behold the Jade Purity of Emptiness and Nothingness, the Ancient One." Vast and immeasurable, most high and most revered, it is as if absent, as if present. Thus, Master Zhang said: "Gazing upon it, one cannot see its form; yet when calling it, it responds with the Three Flowers."

Li (☲) corresponds to the crown of the head, belonging to the south. The south is originally the number three; the crown is the Flower Canopy, also called the Round Canopy. The south belongs to Li, and Li is the position of *wu* (午). The Three Flowers are Golden Flower, Jade Flower, and Ninefold Flower. When the Inner Elixir has coalesced, the crown bears the Three Flowers.

The Great Wondrous Court is the Upper Cinnabar Field—the cavity where the hundred passages converge. The Golden Gate and Jade Chamber: the Sun Palace is the Golden Gate, the left eye; the Moon Palace is the Jade Chamber, the right eye. The Forest of Stars refers to the constellations. It speaks of the sun, moon, and stars arrayed, and the nine orifices of the body becoming clear and luminous.

The Great Flowing Brahmā *Qi* is the wondrous primordial *qi*. "Circulating through the ten directions" describes the wondrous *qi* nourishing and protecting the Golden Embryo’s divine chamber, warming and nurturing the Great Elixir. The above are brief annotations of Daoist practice. There are yet more wondrous subtleties, which must be transmitted heart-to-heart.

Once the inner landscape is revealed, the outer landscape must also be understood. Now, I further explain in terms of worldly methods, so that the wise and foolish alike may each possess eyes and vision.

The Red Script of Primal Chaos emerges from the *qi* of primordial chaos congealing into the Red Script. Once the script emerges, the wondrous scriptures circulate. When the wondrous scriptures circulate, the ancestral *qi* resides within the human body, dispersing into the categories of things—this is called the Supreme Truth of No-Nothingness.

The Primordial Beginning transformed and generated the myriad heavens through the great kalpas. The Primordial Beginning, as the ancestor of the Dao, governs the great kalpas and, with the ancestral *qi*, transforms and generates the myriad heavens. The ancestral *qi* divides into the Three *Qi*, which belong to the Three Pure Realms of the Great Canopy. Thus, it is called the Three Luminaries of Illumination.

Know that this *qi* remains unharmed even through great kalpas—hence, it is called the Heavenly Root. This *qi* is the primordial *qi* of the Great Ultimate, which generates Heaven and Earth, the Five Agents, and the myriad beings. Thus, it is said, "Above, there is no further ancestor." The Dao within the human body is like the *qi* within Heaven and Earth; thus, it is said, "Only the Dao is the body."

When the Crimson Zhangli stands, the Five Patterns unfold and expand; when the scriptural Dharma is practiced, spiritual beings are universally planted. Without scriptural texts, there can be no illumination, no establishment, no self-deliverance. This scripture, self-generated, is the Great Brahma, the sound of the highest rank, the Heaven within Heaven—it is the sacred realm of the Three Pure Ones within the Great Canopy. "Great" means it covers the myriad heavens; "Canopy" means it encompasses the Three Realms. Within it lies the Jade Capital Mountain, eighty thousand *li* in circumference, standing opposite Kunlun below. The mountain bears the Terrace of Lush Radiance, upon which rests a Seven-Treasures City. Above, beyond all bounds, stands the Jade Pure Palace, and further, the Three-Flowered Palace of Detached Convenience, the Great Wondrous Court—all places where the Heavenly Worthies repose and rest. Golden towers and jade chambers, jasper pools and emerald waters, arrayed in solemn order, all depend on the revolving circulation of Brahma-*qi* to endure and persist eternally. Within this realm dwell the spirits who deliver people from death—these are the emanations of the Primordial Beginning. The Lord of Longevity of the Southern Culmen, the Great Emperor of Vermilion Numinosity, governs the Supreme Subtlety Enclosure and oversees the affairs of fire refinement. The Lord of World-Deliverance presides over the transformations of the Nine Hundred and Six Yang calamities. The Lord Sima oversees the eradication of evil and the repelling of trials. The Lord of Good Life, also known as the alternate name of Azure Florescence, presides over the verification and assessment. Lord Han oversees the ranks and studies of the disciples of Southern Prosperity. The Lords of Life and Record govern merit and transgression, bestowal and deprivation, extending lifespan and augmenting destiny. The Venerable Spirit of Deliverance from Tribulation presides over the pacification of calamities and the reversal of death. The Lord oversees the ascension and deliverance of the dead, raising the flying corpses to the dawn. Now, as the Heavenly Worthy expounds the Dharma and descends to the imperial terrace, examining charts and reviewing records, assessing and delivering disciples—it is as if the human body were no different from the Jade Capital. Golden towers and jade chambers, cinnabar fields and muddy pellets, arrayed in profound order: when the *qi* of the body’s spirits is full, the spirit of immortality dwells within, just as the Brahma-*qi* of the Jade Capital revolves without decay.

The ode says:
On Jade Capital Mountain’s Terrace of Lush Radiance,
The highest scriptures expound ten cycles.
Universally planting spiritual beings, the Brahma-darkness moves,
The Three Flowers detach, the Five Lines unfold.

The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless East, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless South, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless West, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless North, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless Northeast, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless Southeast, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless Southwest, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless Northwest, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless Above, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance;
The Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Boundless Below, Great Saints of Longevity and Immeasurable Deliverance—
The Perfected Flying Heavenly Spirit-Kings of the Ten Directions, Great Spirits of Longevity and Immeasurable World-Deliverance,
All ride upon flying clouds, cinnabar chariots and green carriages,
Feathered canopies and jasper wheels,
Drawn by vermilion phoenixes and five-colored dark dragons,
Bearing nine-colored standards and ten mystic banners.
Ahead, nine phoenixes roar in unison;
Behind, eight simurghs sing in harmony.
Lions and white cranes chant in melodious chorus,
While the Five Elders clear the path and the host of immortals flank the procession.

Myriad chariots and ten thousand riders arrive floating through the void,
Their radiant light turned back, they oversee the perfected and deliver the living.

Master Shangyangzi says: The Flying Heavenly Great Saints of the Ten Directions are all emanations of the Primordial Dao’s qi. Their taboo names are:
East: Zong
South: Fei
West: Yun
North: Wujing
Northeast: Fan
Southeast: Nayu
Southwest: Duxian
Northwest: Jueqi
Above: Ying
Below: Luo

They are also called the Ten Directions’ Great Saints of Longevity, or the Ten Directions’ Heavenly Worthies Who Save from Suffering. By the mandate of the Primordial Beginning, they govern the weighing of merits and virtues across the Ten Directions and Three Realms, opening deliverance to the boundless, encompassing life and death, and refining the adepts.

The *Hidden Canon* records that in the heavens of the Eight Directions, there exist Boundless Great Thousandfold Worlds:
The Boundless Heavens of the East hold the Great Thousandfold World of Nadatangxiang, the Realm of Gathering Goodness;
The Boundless Heavens of the South hold the Great Thousandfold World of Wanlichengjing, the Realm of Forsaking the Worthy;
The Boundless Heavens of the West hold the Great Thousandfold World of Futangzhou, the Realm of Universal Conduct;
The Boundless Heavens of the North hold the Great Thousandfold World of Yudanye, the Realm of Purity;
The Boundless Heavens of the Northeast hold the Great Thousandfold World of Fujidu, the Realm of Eternal Peace;
The Boundless Heavens of the Southeast hold the Great Thousandfold World of Yuanfutian, the Realm of Employing the Worthy;
The Boundless Heavens of the Southwest hold the Great Thousandfold World of Yanfuxiang, the Realm of Benevolent Stillness;
The Boundless Heavens of the Northwest hold the Great Thousandfold World of Fudeye, the Realm of Extending Worthiness;
The Upper Heavens of Supreme Purity’s Jade Perfection hold the Thirty-Six Heavens of Xuandu, the Boundless World;
The Lower Heavens of Huangzeng hold the Thirty-Two Heavens of Bayuan, the Boundless World.

The boundless great spirits oversee the affairs of attaining the Dao, longevity, and world-deliverance.

The Perfected of Azure Origin says: Chariots, wheels, and canopies are formed from the qi of yang essence; phoenixes, cranes, dragons, and simurghs are transformations of the qi of yin essence. The perfected saints, possessing the constant Dao, harmonize their breath—gathering and dispersing at will, manifesting as they please. The harmony of yin and yang qi resembles song and melody, all wrought by qi, not external things. When a person’s returning elixir is complete, the yin demons are also transformed into yang spirits. With a single breath of primordial qi, the myriad spirits all heed; the spirits of the five viscera each appear in their directional colors. The chariots, carriages, and retinue come to welcome, the hundred bones’ host of spirits lead the way, and the following ascent to the Primordial is no different.

The Five Elders who clear the path are:
The Azure Spirit Elder of the East, surnamed Guan, taboo name Kai, style Lingweiyang;
The Cinnabar Spirit Perfected Elder of the South, surnamed Dongfu, taboo name Jiyan, style Chibiaonu;
The Primordial Spirit Primordial Elder of the Center, surnamed Tongban, taboo name Yuanshi, style Hanzhuniu;
The Radiant Spirit August Elder of the West, surnamed Shangjin, taboo name Changkai, style Yaopobao;
The Dark Spirit Mysterious Elder of the North, surnamed Heijie, taboo name Linghui, style Yinhouju.

The Great Saints of the Ten Directions, exalted in their Dao rank, thus evoke the Five Elders to clear the path while the host of immortals flanks the procession. Myriad chariots and ten thousand riders arrive floating through the void—yet all are the divine bodies of the Dharma.

The *Elixir Canon* states: The spirit rides the qi, and the qi abides in form. Their radiant light turned back, jade light and flying clouds swirl around the Dharma-throne of the Heavenly Worthies, leading and overseeing the assembly of perfected, assessing and delivering the ranks of lords. In alchemical terms, “turning back the radiant light” signifies the completion of the Kan-Li union, the intercourse of yin and yang, the transformation and birth of the true spirit, and the nurturing of the embryo chamber—hence, “overseeing the perfected and delivering the living.”

A hymn says:
The Heavenly Perfected of the Boundless gather in the Palace of Medicines,
Cinnabar and simurgh carriages ride the floating void.
Turning back the radiant light, the host of immortals rejoices—
Yang grows, yin wanes: the wondrous work of transformation.

The Chancellors of the Heavens, the Supreme Palace of Nanchang, the Recorder Han, the Great Spirit Who Oversees Life—holding registers and grasping ledgers, they all arrive before the Emperor. According to whom deliverance is due, they strictly assess the heavens. Universally proclaimed to the Three Realms, the Boundless Spirit Regions, the Yellow Springs’ courts, the Northern Capital of Fengdu, the Three Offices and Nine Bureaus, the Twelve River Sources: the ancestors and forebears of a thousand kalpas, the kin of countless eons—swiftly erase their ledgers of sins, sever their roots of evil, and forbid their detention or coercion into ghostly throngs. By the talismanic mandate of the Primordial Beginning, they ascend in due time. From the Cold Pool of the Northern Capital, their forms and souls are escorted, demons restrained, and merits protected—delivered to the Southern Palace for ranking. The souls of the dead undergo refinement and transform into immortals; the living who receive deliverance endure through kalpas, everlasting. Through kalpas they revolve, their years equaling Heaven’s. Forever delivered from the Three Paths, Five Sufferings, and Eight Difficulties, they transcend the Three Realms and roam freely in the Supreme Purity.

The Heaven of Supreme Purity is the Realm of the Heavenly Emperor’s Jade Perfection, the Formless Realm of Brahma-conduct.

Master Shangyangzi says: This Dao employs both the methods of the Dao and the principles of the world—both must be understood.

In worldly terms:
The Chancellors of the Heavens—each heaven has its chancellor, also called the Great Luo Divine Duke. Nanchang is the world of the Cinnabar Heaven; the Supreme Palace is the Scarlet Numinous Fire Mansion. The Venerable One of the Han Bureau is the Controller of Destiny. He oversees the affairs of refining and delivering the records. The Recorder is the celestial minister who assists the Heavenly Emperor in recording. The Office of Registers oversees the forging of souls. When the Most High expounds the scriptures, each holds their ledgers and arrives before the Emperor to assess those due for deliverance. Some are destined by their names in the Mysterious Register or their bone configurations for immortality; others accumulate merits through cultivation, observance of precepts, or reverence for the Three Treasures, their good deeds piercing Heaven; still others make offerings to the masters and treasures, praised by the Three Offices. Those whose names are in the heavens undergo strict examination and assessment, their merits measured and ranks determined—according to their excellence, they receive ascent and deliverance.

In Daoist terms:
Holding registers and grasping ledgers, the qi of the Primordial Beginning divides, and yin and yang separate; the Three Powers are established, and the records arise. The *Inner Meaning* states: Manifesting in benevolence, they become ledgers; concealed in function, they become yin and yang. Without ledgers in the hidden and manifest, how could merits and sins be recorded? Without yin and yang in Heaven and Earth, how could creation be accomplished? Thus, the Emperor’s presence is the divine chamber of the Central Palace, where the Emperor resides—all seas converge like spokes to a hub, where spirits abide—all qi coalesces in harmony.

Just as yin and yang converge within the Central Palace’s divine chamber, so it is said: grasping ledgers and holding registers, all arrive in unison before the Emperor. The Heavenly Worthy’s scriptural teachings are no empty words—they urge people to practice the Way.

Those who cultivate and study must first correct their faults and turn toward goodness, uphold precepts and guard against lust, abandon deceit and still their scheming, purify the heart and reduce desires. Alas! Worldly people chase the trivial and forget the fundamental, devalue life and treat the body lightly. The heroic and bold are enslaved by fame and merit; the wise and exceptional are shackled by ambition; the well-clothed and well-fed are trapped by their schemes; the poor and destitute are burdened by their bodily needs. Even those who leave the dusty world, delighting in ease and comfort, mistakenly believe that emptiness and non-action alone constitute cultivation—how could they ever attain the convergence of yin and yang within the divine chamber?

As for those who are to be delivered, the Way of the Golden Elixir demands true effort, and rewards follow according to merit. With ten parts effort comes ten parts reward; even a single lapse yields a corresponding deficiency. Though one’s practice may be most secret and one’s deeds unknown, in the vast Heaven of Great Purity, all is strictly examined and recorded.

A universal proclamation is issued to the Three Realms—the Realm of Desire, the Realm of Form, and the Formless Realm—as well as to the Three Realms of Heaven, Earth, and Water. The boundless divine homeland, the ten directions’ infinite worlds, are also the divine courts of the Three Realms, the bureaus of the Temple of the Yellow Springs. In the north lies the great sea, where the viscera spirits manifest in colors corresponding to their directions.

Chariots and carriages, ceremonial guards come to welcome; the myriad spirits of the body lead the way, followed by ascension to audience with the Primordial. This is no different. The Five Elders open the path: in the east, the Azure Spirit First Elder, surnamed Guan, named Kai, styled Lingwei Yang; in the south, the Cinnabar Spirit True Elder, surnamed Dongfu, named Jiyan, styled Chibiao Nu; in the center, the Primordial Spirit Primordial Elder, surnamed Tongban, named Yuanshi, styled Hanzhu Niu; in the west, the Radiant Spirit August Elder, surnamed Shangjin, named Changkai, styled Yaopo Bao; in the north, the Five Spirits Mysterious Elder, surnamed Heijie, named Linghui, styled Yinhou Ju.

The great sages of the ten directions, whose Dao-ranks are most exalted, move the Five Elders to open the way, and the host of immortals flanks their carriage—countless chariots and myriad riders arrive floating through the void, yet all are the divine bodies of the Dharma. As the *Elixir Canon* states: “The spirit rides the qi, and the qi sustains the form.” The light pours forth, the chariot turns back; jade radiance and flying clouds swirl around the Heavenly Worthy’s dharma-seat. Leading and overseeing the host of perfected ones, they assess and deliver according to rank.

In elixir terms, the pouring forth of light and turning back of the chariot signify the completion of the Kan-Li union, the convergence of yin and yang, the transformation and birth of the true spirit, the nurturing within the womb-chamber—hence, “overseeing the perfected and delivering the living.” The ode says:
*In the Infinite Heaven’s true alchemy palace,*
*Elixir and karma-chariots ride the void.*
*The light pours forth, the chariot turns—hosts of immortals rejoice,*
*Yang grows, yin wanes: the wondrous work of transformation.*

The celestial chancellors of the various heavens, the Southern Prosperity Upper Palace, Han the Controller of the Registers, the Great Spirit overseeing life—grasping ledgers and holding registers, all arrive in unison before the Emperor. According to those who are to be delivered, the heavens are strictly examined.

A universal proclamation is issued to the Three Realms, the boundless divine homeland, the bureaus of the Yellow Springs, the Northern Capital of Fengdu, the Three Offices and Nine Bureaus, the Twelve River Sources. Ancestral karmic bonds spanning kalpas are dissolved; sins are swiftly erased from the ledgers, evil roots severed. They must not be detained or forced into the company of ghosts. By the Primordial Beginning’s talismanic decree, they ascend in due time from the Northern Capital’s icy pools. Their forms and souls are guarded, demons restrained, merits protected, and ranks delivered to the Southern Palace. The dead souls undergo refinement and transform into immortals; the living receive deliverance and endure through kalpas, turning with the cycles of time, their years equaling Heaven’s. Forever delivered from the Three Paths, the Five Sufferings, and the Eight Difficulties, they transcend the Three Realms and roam freely in the Upper Clarity.

The Heaven of Upper Clarity is the Heavenly Emperor’s Jade Perfection, the formless realm of pure conduct. Master Shangyang said: “This concerns both the application of the Way and worldly principles—both must be made clear.”

Worldly principles:
The celestial chancellors of the various heavens. Each heaven has its own chancellor, also called the Great Purity Divine Duke. Southern Prosperity is the Cinnabar Heaven world; the Upper Palace is the Vermilion Numinous Fire Bureau. The Venerable Han of the Controller’s Palace is the Director of Destinies. He oversees the refinement and deliverance of records. The Controller of the Registers is the Celestial Prime Minister who assists the Heavenly Emperor in managing records. The Bureau of Engraved Registers oversees the forging of souls and refining of spirits.

The Most High expounds the scriptures, each holding their ledgers and registers, all arriving in unison before the Emperor to assess those who are to receive deliverance. Deliverance comes to those whose names are inscribed in the mysterious charts of former lives, whose bone configurations align with immortality; or those who cultivate and uphold precepts, whose accumulated merits and virtues move Heaven; or those who revere the Three Treasures, whose good deeds reach the heavens, or who honor the master’s treasure and are commended by the Three Offices. Those whose names are recorded in the heavens undergo strict examination and assessment, their merits measured and ranks determined—according to their excellence, they receive ascent and deliverance.

In Daoist terms:
Holding registers and grasping ledgers, the qi of the Primordial Beginning divides, and yin and yang separate; the Three Powers are established, and the records arise. The *Inner Meaning* states: Manifesting in benevolence, they become ledgers; concealed in function, they become yin and yang. Without ledgers in the hidden and manifest, how could merits and sins be recorded? Without yin and yang in Heaven and Earth, how could creation be accomplished? Thus, the Emperor’s presence is the divine chamber of the Central Palace, where the Emperor resides—all seas converge like spokes to a hub, where spirits abide—all qi coalesces in harmony. This illustrates the convergence of yin and yang within the Central Palace’s divine chamber, hence the saying: grasping ledgers and holding registers, all arrive in unison before the Emperor. The Heavenly Worthy’s scriptural teachings are no empty words—they urge people to practice the Way.

Those of transcendent disposition who delight only in ease and comfort, supposing that purity and non-action alone constitute cultivation, are gravely mistaken. How could they attain the union of yin and yang within the divine chamber? In accordance with what each is destined to deliver, the Way of the Golden Elixir demands true effort, and rewards follow in proportion to merit. With ten parts of effort comes ten parts of fruition; even a single lapse yields but a fragmented reward. Though one’s practice be most secret and one’s deeds unknown, yet in the vastness of the Great Brahma Heaven, all is strictly examined and recorded.

A universal proclamation is made to the Three Realms—Desire Realm, Form Realm, and Formless Realm—which are also the Three Realms of Heaven, Earth, and Water. The boundless divine homeland, the ten directions’ infinite worlds, are likewise the divine courts of the Three Realms, the palaces of the sacred springs and hidden valleys. In the north lies the Great Sea, the bowstring-qi of the north. *Ming* (命) means the wondrous, the lead, the yang within yin, the bowstring-qi of the tiger. As the *Classic* states: “Abide in non-desire to observe its mystery; abide in desire to observe its gateway.” Thus the ancients said: “He who writes talismans without knowing the gateway invites the mockery of spirits.” *Laozi* says: “The gateway is dark and obscure, yet within it lies essence; this essence is most true; within it lies trust.” This trust is the talismanic trust. It is the primordial talismanic mandate, wherein the true qi of the Primordial Beginning harmonizes with the ancestral qi of the Gate of Life.

Why is this so? The human body is endowed with the ancestral qi of the Primordial Beginning at birth, yet in the prime of life, one stumbles into the realm of intoxication and dreams, and this qi flees and is lost. For the cultivator, one must first refine the yin within yang to retain true mercury, then refine the yang within yin to seek true lead. In a single moment of concentration, the Elixir coalesces, and one may hope for ascension and promotion. The Northern Capital is the root of nature, where true mercury flourishes. The Cold Pool is the Gate of Life, where true lead flourishes. When lead and mercury unite, nature and life merge, and one must seize the moment with a single thought to guard the body and the hun-soul. If the form is whole and the hun-soul restored, the pulse halts and qi ceases, the Reverted Elixir begins to form—thus one can subdue demons, ensure promotion, and pass through the Southern Palace for ranking. The so-called withered corpse and dying hun-soul, refined by this lead-fire, attain the wondrous transformation of divine immortality and become perfected beings.

To deliver the living body—this single phrase revealed by the Heavenly Worthy clarifies the essence of the Reverted Elixir. For this scripture speaks not only for the dead, but for the living practitioner who receives this true qi for deliverance. Moreover, in the living body, yin and yang may be made whole, and the workings of creation grasped. If the practitioner, within this mortal frame, can invert the Five Phases and cultivate this Great Elixir to become a lofty immortal, then one may endure for kalpas unending, revolving through the ages, sharing the lifespan of Heaven, forever escaping the Eight Difficulties, transcending the Desire Realm, Form Realm, and Formless Realm, rising above the Four Kinds of Heavenly Beings, and roaming freely in the Upper Clarity.

Xue Youqi said: The Upper Clarity has thirty-six heavens, whose heavenly emperors are equal in Dao to the Primordial Beginning, their ranks arrayed in the Jade Clarity. Thus it is said that the Jade Perfected reside beyond the Formless Realm, outside the bounds of creation, moving by the qi of Brahmanic contemplation, passing in and out without obstruction. They are not like the thirty-two heavens confined within the Three Realms. Hence it is called the Brahmanic practice. The ode states:

The Heavenly Emperors and Jade Perfected of the six-six heavens,
When the Elixir is complete and the Dao perfected, share Heaven’s years.
Form and spirit both wondrous, their merit fulfilled,
For kalpas unending they endure as Upper Immortals.

Some versions mistakenly attribute the name of this Heavenly Emperor to the *Primordial Numinous Writ, Upper Chapter*. Yet they fail to recognize that the *Heavenly Duke’s Scripture* states: The Great Brahma Heaven has its own *Numinous Writ, Upper Chapter*, along with the *Observing Awareness* and the *Coiled Dragon Seal Script*, contained within the *Numinous Writ, Middle Chapter*. The Former Shu edition sometimes places it in the Lower Chapter—this too is incorrect. The Azure Perfected said: One should follow the *Heavenly Duke’s Scripture*. This is correct.

The Eight Heavens of the East are formed from the Primordial Beginning’s accumulation of ninefold yang Brahmanic qi. Six heavens belong to the Desire Realm, and two to the Form Realm. The Heavenly Emperors’ regalia are all azure.

The Supreme August Yellow-Pervaded Heaven, also called the Pure Heaven or the Witnessing History. Its color is yellow, next to Kui and Bi. Those who cultivate the ten virtues and purify a single sense faculty are reborn here. The Buddhists call this the Heaven of the Four Heavenly Kings. The Emperor’s name is Yu Jian Yu Ming. The correct pronunciation is Kai Xuan She Ming. The Heavenly Emperor’s inner name is Yu Lan; the demonic emperor’s hidden meaning is Yu Ming. These four characters are secret to the Purple Ultimate Palace of Heaven, which governs the Register of Longevity.

The Supreme Brightness Jade-Perfected Heaven, also called the Victorious and Wondrous Heaven. Its color is green, next to Pi. Those who cultivate twenty virtues and purify two sense faculties are reborn here. The Buddhists call this the Trāyastriṃśa Heaven. The Emperor’s name is Xu A Na Tian.
