chunks.original_text: 然体元始之意，大@唯欲存道。 说经以明道，使人知敬此道； 出经以泄道，欲人知行此道，是道为经之体，经为道之用。 因经显道，因道寻经。 世之凡夫，闻经则敬，闻道则笑。 遇经则琅琅而念诵，闻道则成群而毁谤。 只如道为母，经为子，世未有爱其子而晋其母也。 道之所以开天地、揭日月、施风雨、役雷霆、今人闻雷霆则掩耳，闻道则非笑，太上虽慈悲而不加谴，然人之自取沉坠者，为当何如。 何谓道，何谓经？ 全阴阳造化者谓之道，全性命体用者谓之经。 有阴而无阳，不可以为道； 有体而无用，不可以为经； 是道为阴阳之根，经乃性命之用，以真性合元命，是配阴阳以外形合内神，是全体用。 夫唯元始还丹之道，与人受胎本同。 人受凡父母精血之初，亦溟涬混沌而无形。 精血既安，一月为胞，二月成胎，三月生魂，四月定魄，五月分五脏，六月开六腑，七月明七窍，八月具八景，九月相足，十月气全、脱胎而生。 还丹之道，正类是也。 其受灵父圣母妙气之初，必九和十合，而金炁始来，亦溟涬混沌、洞虚寥廓，无色无渊之可倚，无形无影之可依。 元炁安镇，五行敷落，弥罗周回，冥然凝合，况啸朗营，复元归空，摄聚郁辅，含孕怀真。 生五脏、理五炁、合百神、结胎婴，号曰阳神出入神化。 但人受凡父母精血，而生其质，不灵金丹是灵父圣母之黑，而毓能变化飞行，是谓性命双修，形神俱妙。 颂日：混合百神赖此经，此经尊妙甚分明。 天中梵炁胎婴就，万炁齐仙步玉京。 中有空洞谣歌之章，魔王灵篇，辞参高真。 第一欲界飞空之音： 人道眇眇，仙道莽莽。 鬼道乐兮，当人生门。 天道贵生，鬼道贵终。 仙道常自吉，鬼道常自凶。 高上清灵爽，悲歌朗太空。 惟愿仙道成，不欲人道穷。 北都泉曲府，中有万鬼群。 但欲遏人算，断绝人命门。 阿人歌洞章，以摄北罗酆。 束送妖魔精，斩馘六鬼锋。 诸天炁荡荡，我道日兴隆。 上阳子曰：《灵宝经法》云：洞章乃龟山丹黄飞玄紫文，非魔王所为。 尹真人侍老君西道龟台，入七宝园，观其文修之有法，布此三章于世，令人开悟，超出三界。 昔天尊降魔，魔王悉皆稽首受事。 乃勅魔王郁默统治欲界，勅魔王摩罗统治色界。 勅魔王无明治无色界。 各歌谣章，变化飞空，警戒天人，屏绝欲鬼。 令人闻此飞空之音，转色欲苦，归清净门。 自黄曾至摩夷为欲界，六欲俱净，则升色界。 人道眇眇，微而阳失； 仙道莽莽，高远难明。 生门者，生人生物之门，成仙作佛之门。 钟离真人曰：生我之门死我户，即此，门也。 为人不悟，则欲鬼当此之门为乐。 天道好生，为贵而人，苦趣鬼道。 高上清灵爽。 高上之人，心清性灵，其辞爽慨，悲悯愚惑，谣歌朗彻太空。 葛仙翁《流珠歌》曰：流珠流珠，役我区区。 忙忙汲汲，忘寝失哺。 吾今六十，忧赴三涂。 真人度我，要大丈夫。 谛观斯语，岂非悲歌朗太空者乎！ 太上留经之意，愿世人修证仙道，不欲人趋邪道而终穷也。 北都泉曲府，世之欲海，中有万鬼群，总皆色类。 若人耽迷，则遏算而绝命根。 学人为阿人，或居色界，时歌洞章，摄伏罗酆。 盖北都罗酆乃人之欲根也。 欲根才动，罗酆起漫漫之黑云，六鬼交锋，妖精趋淋淋之苦雨。
chunks.translated_text:
Yet the intent of the Primordial Origin lies solely in preserving the Dao/Way.
Expounding scriptures clarifies the Dao/Way, that people may revere it;
Revealing scriptures unfolds the Dao/Way, that people may practice it.
Thus the Dao/Way is the essence of scripture, and scripture the function of the Dao/Way.
Through scripture the Dao/Way is revealed; through the Dao/Way scripture is sought.

Worldly commoners, upon hearing scripture, show reverence;
Upon hearing the Dao/Way, they laugh.
Encountering scripture, they chant it aloud with fervor;
Hearing the Dao/Way, they gather to slander it.
Yet the Dao/Way is the mother, scripture the child—
Never has the world loved the child while reviling the mother.

The Dao/Way is that by which heaven and earth unfold,
By which sun and moon are raised,
By which wind and rain are dispensed,
By which thunder and lightning are commanded.
Yet when people hear thunder and lightning, they cover their ears;
When they hear the Dao/Way, they ridicule it.
Though the Most High is merciful and does not punish,
How dire is the self-inflicted downfall of such people!

What is the Dao/Way? What is scripture?
That which completes the transformations of yin and yang is called the Dao/Way;
That which fulfills the essence and function of life and nature is called scripture.
Without yang to balance yin, it cannot be the Dao/Way;
Without function to complement essence, it cannot be scripture.
Thus the Dao/Way is the root of yin and yang,
And scripture the function of life and nature.
To unite true nature with primordial life is to pair yin and yang;
To harmonize outer form with inner spirit is to complete essence and function.

The Dao/Way of the Primordial Origin’s returning elixir is akin to the conception of human life.
When a person receives the essence and blood of ordinary parents,
It too begins as a formless, chaotic vastness.
Once essence and blood settle, in the first month it becomes an embryo;
In the second, a fetus;
In the third, the hun-soul is born;
In the fourth, the po-soul is fixed;
In the fifth, the five viscera take shape;
In the sixth, the six bowels open;
In the seventh, the seven orifices become clear;
In the eighth, the eight luminous scenes are complete;
In the ninth, the limbs are fully formed;
In the tenth, the qi is whole, and the child emerges from the womb.

The Dao/Way of the returning elixir follows the same pattern.
When it receives the wondrous qi of the numinous father and sagely mother,
Only after nine harmonies and ten unions does the golden qi arrive—
Also a formless, chaotic vastness, an empty and boundless expanse,
Without color or depth to rely upon,
Without form or shadow to depend on.
Once the primordial qi is settled,
The five phases unfold,
Enveloping and revolving in silent fusion,
Radiant and resplendent,
Returning to the void,
Gathering and nurturing,
Conceiving and bearing the true.
The five viscera are born,
The five qi are ordered,
The hundred spirits are united,
The fetal immortal is knit—
This is called the yang-spirit, emerging and transforming through divine power.
Yet while ordinary people receive the essence and blood of mortal parents to form their bodies,
The golden elixir is nurtured by the numinous father and sagely mother,
Enabling transformation and flight—
This is the dual cultivation of life and nature, the wondrous union of form and spirit.

A hymn says:
*By this scripture, the hundred spirits merge in harmony;
This scripture’s sublimity is most clear.
Within the heavens, the celestial qi perfects the fetal immortal;
The myriad qi ascend together as immortals to the Jade Capital.*

Within it are the empty and resounding chants,
The demon-subduing scriptures of the numinous chapters,
Their verses attuned to the loftiest perfected beings.

First, the celestial hymns of the Desire Realm in flight:
*The human path is faint, the immortal path vast.
The ghostly path delights—yet it is the gateway of human life.
The heavenly path values life, the ghostly path values death.
The immortal path is ever auspicious, the ghostly path ever ominous.
O exalted, pure, and numinous soul,
Sing your lament, resounding through the great void!
I wish only for the immortal path’s fulfillment,
Not for the human path’s exhaustion.*

*The Northern Capital, the Spring-Curved Prefecture,
Holds a host of ten thousand ghosts.
They seek only to cut short human destiny,
To sever the gateway of life.*
The adept sings the cavernous chapters,
To subdue the Northern Feng.
Binding and dispatching demonic spirits,
Severing the blades of the six ghosts.
*The qi of the heavens surges boundlessly;
My Dao/Way flourishes day by day.*

Master Shangyang said: *The Scripture of Numinous Treasure Methods* states that the cavernous chapters are the *Cinnabar Yellow, Flying Mystery, Purple Writ* of Mount Gui—
Not the work of demon kings.
When Perfected Lord Yin attended the Most High on the Western Terrace of Mount Gui,
He entered the Seven Treasures Garden,
Observed the proper method of its composition,
And disseminated these three chapters to the world,
That people might awaken and transcend the Three Realms.

In ancient times, when the Heavenly Worthy subdued the demons,
The demon kings all bowed their heads and accepted their charge.
The Heavenly Worthy commanded Demon King Yumo to govern the Desire Realm,
Demon King Moluo to govern the Form Realm,
And Demon King Wuoming to govern the Formless Realm.
Each sang their hymns,
Transforming and soaring through the void,
Warning and admonishing heavenly beings,
Banishing desire-demons.
That people, upon hearing these celestial hymns in flight,
Might turn from the suffering of sensual desire
And return to the gate of purity.

From the Yellow Citadel to the Mafi Realm is the Desire Realm;
When the six desires are wholly purified, one ascends to the Form Realm.
*The human path is faint, its yang lost in obscurity;
The immortal path is vast, lofty and hard to fathom.*
The *Gateway of Life* is the portal of human and all beings’ birth,
The gateway of becoming an immortal or a buddha.
Perfected Lord Zhongli said:
*The gate that gives me life is the door that takes my death*—
This is that very gate.
If one fails to awaken, desire-demons delight in this gateway.

The *Exalted, Pure, and Numinous Soul*—
The exalted one, with a pure heart and numinous nature,
Sings with forthright lament,
Pitying the deluded,
Their chants resounding through the great void.
Master Ge’s *Song of the Flowing Pearl* says:
*Flowing pearl, flowing pearl,
You drive me to toil endlessly.
Hurrying, bustling,
Forgetting sleep and food.
Now at sixty, I fear the three wretched destinies.
A perfected one delivers me—
It takes a great man!*
Pondering these words,
Is this not the lament resounding through the great void?

The intent of the Most High in leaving these scriptures
Is that the world’s people cultivate and realize the immortal path,
Not that they follow the deviant path to their ultimate ruin.

The *Northern Capital, Spring-Curved Prefecture*—
The world’s sea of desire—
Holds a host of ten thousand ghosts,
All of the realm of sensual forms.
If one is lost in infatuation,
They will cut short one’s destiny and sever the root of life.
The adept, dwelling in the Form Realm,
Sings the cavernous chapters at times,
Subduing Feng of the North.
For the Northern Feng is the root of human desire.
When the root of desire stirs,
Feng arises in billowing black clouds,
The six ghosts clash their blades,
And demonic spirits rush forth in a deluge of suffering.

chunks.original_text: 学人到此，要降伏之，变欲界而为长乐，以炼还丹化鬼妖而为诸天。 以施灵药则金光之炁荡荡，而我丹道日兴隆矣。 颂曰：伶俐惺惺日夜忙，谁分地狱与天堂。 好将冷眼看浮世，唤醒阿人歌洞章。 第二色界魔王之章： 落落高张，明炁四骞。 梵行诸天，周回十方。 无量大神，皆由我身。 我有洞章，万徧成仙。 仙道贵度，鬼道相连。 天地渺莽，秽炁氛氛。 三界乐兮，过之长存。 身度我界，体入自然。 此时乐兮，薄由我恩。 龙汉荡荡，何能别真。 我界难度，故作洞文。 变化飞空，以试尔身。 成败懈退，度者几人。 笑尔不度，故为歌音。 自越行天至昙誓天，共一十八天，为色界。 此天之人有形无欲，分粗细轻，一十八尘。 尘染俱净，升无色界。 落落高张，色天远大，明炁四骞，梵炁朗明，无量大神。 我身魔试，洞章万徧，结习皆忘。 仙道贵度，出于色界。 鬼道欲人，相连色界。 丹阳真人，东州富室，日唯耽乐； 重阳祖师，特征度之。 一见即曰：我来扶醉人。 丹阳瞋曰：如何是道？ 曰：五行不到处。 丹阳大悟，从学登仙。 此岂非仙道贵度者乎？ 天地渺莽，色境何穷。 《南华经》云：物来无穷，我心有际； 秽炁氛氛，结而不散； 三界乐兮，过之长存； 过此色界，超三界天，升上清境，可以长存。 身度我界，体入自然，色超色类，不为所迷。 得大自在，薄由我恩，因经悟道，龙汉荡荡，真伪莫分，我界难度，色相未除，岂能度脱魔境？ 故作洞章之文以相勉。 又变化飞空，以魔试其问，成者少，败懈退者多。 笑尔不能出此色境，故为歌谣此文也。 颂曰：色界天中十八尘，此心未净即非真，要知我界何难度，度者如今有几人。 第三无色界魔王歌曰： 三界之上，眇眇大罗。 上无色根，云层峨峨。 唯有元始，浩劫之家，部制我界，统乘玄都。 有过我界，身入玉虚。 我位上王，匡御众魔。 空中万变，秽炁氛葩。 保真者少，迷惑者多。 仙道难固，鬼道易邪。 人道者心，谅不由他。 仙道贵实，人道贵华。 尔不乐仙道，三界那得过。 其欲转五道，我当复奈何。 自皓庭至秀乐四天为元色界。 《太真科》曰：无色界中，至真无情，色欲俱空，无复形质之患。 修至一天，唯存心识，以入炁观，炁观道成，上升一天。 又能去除心识，以至无为，复升一天。 若万法在心，若有若无，又升一天。 若炁观转妙，结习都忘，洞入自然，即升种民天也。 《本际经》曰； 烦恼为结，学业为习； 结习已尽，超种民位，洞入道境，随炁升降，灾所不及也。 青元真人,曰：无色界中虽能离染忘色，然未能遣忘，尤以心识为患，故有秽炁氛葩，则鬼道易为邪入，偶失制御，即坠色界。 直须忘心，自遣观空入妙。 《老君经》曰：所空既无，无无亦无，湛然常寂，方是真静。 昔浪子刘长生真人洛阳三年，日唯观空遣忘，爱根才动，便乃诵曰：北都泉曲府，中有万鬼郡； 但欲遏人算，断绝人命门。 诵此谣章，爱根斩然； 岂非阿人歌洞章以摄北罗酆者乎？ 此为真实工夫，所谓仙道贵实也。 世皆耽迷，不乐仙道，转轮五苦，须欲提技，复奈之何。 颂曰：无色天中甚磨无，这回心地莫糊涂。 他家不是闲花草，要把真身入玉虚。 此三界之上，飞空之中，魔王歌音，音参洞章。
chunks.translated_text:
When the adept reaches this stage,
They must subdue and transform it,
Turning the Realm of Desire into Eternal Bliss,
Refining the elixir to transmute ghosts and demons into the hosts of heaven.
By bestowing the numinous medicine,
The radiant qi of golden light billows forth,
And my Dao of the elixir flourishes day by day.

A hymn says:
Busy day and night, sharp and clever,
Who distinguishes hell from heaven?
With a cold eye, observe the floating world,
Awaken the adept to sing the cavernous chapters.

**Second: The Chapter of the Color Realm’s Demon Kings**

Lofty and vast, resplendent,
Luminous qi soars in the four directions.
The Brahma-conduct heavens encircle the ten directions,
Boundless great spirits—all arise from my body.
I possess the cavernous chapters,
Ten thousand recitations make one an immortal.
The Dao of immortals values deliverance,
While the ghostly path clings to the Realm of Color.
Heaven and earth stretch boundless,
Defiled qi swirls thickly.
The bliss of the Three Realms—
Pass beyond it to abide forever.
When the body crosses my realm,
It merges with the natural.
At this moment of bliss,
All is by my grace.
The Dragon Han era flows on—
How can one discern the true?
My realm is hard to cross,
Thus I compose the cavernous scriptures.
Transforming and soaring through the void,
I test your body.
Success or failure, slackening or retreat—
How few are those who cross!
I laugh at those who do not cross,
Thus I sing this melody.

From the Heaven of Self-Exceeding Conduct to the Heaven of Cloud Vows,
Eighteen heavens comprise the Realm of Color.
The people of these heavens possess form but no desire,
Distinguished by coarse, fine, and subtle dust—eighteen specks in all.
When the dust’s defilements are wholly purified,
One ascends to the Formless Realm.

Lofty and vast, the heavens of color stretch far and wide,
Luminous qi soars in the four directions,
Brahma-qi shines brightly,
Boundless great spirits.
My body is tested by demons,
The cavernous chapters recited ten thousand times,
All habitual tendencies forgotten.
The Dao of immortals values deliverance,
Emerging from the Realm of Color.
The ghostly path entices people,
Clinging to the Realm of Color.

Master Danyang, a wealthy man of the Eastern Land,
Indulged in pleasure day and night.
Patriarch Chongyang specially sought to deliver him.
At their first meeting, he said:
“I come to support a drunken man.”
Danyang angrily asked: “What is the Dao?”
He replied: “Where the five phases do not reach.”
Danyang had a great awakening,
Followed him to study, and ascended as an immortal.
Is this not the value the Dao of immortals places on deliverance?

Heaven and earth stretch boundless,
The bounds of the color realm endless.
The *Nanhua Sutra* says:
Things come without end,
But my mind has its limits.
Defiled qi swirls thickly,
Congealing and not dispersing.
The bliss of the Three Realms—
Pass beyond it to abide forever.
Beyond this Realm of Color,
Transcend the heavens of the Three Realms,
Ascend to the Upper Clarity,
And there you may abide forever.
When the body crosses my realm,
It merges with the natural,
Transcending the forms of color,
No longer deluded by them.
Attaining great freedom,
All is by my grace.
Through the scriptures, one awakens to the Dao.
The Dragon Han era flows on—
True and false cannot be distinguished.
My realm is hard to cross.
If the forms of color are not eradicated,
How can one escape the demonic realm?
Thus I compose the cavernous scriptures to encourage you.
Again, transforming and soaring through the void,
I test you with demons.
Few succeed; many fail, slacken, or retreat.
I laugh at those who cannot emerge from this realm of color,
Thus I sing this song.

A hymn says:
In the heavens of the Color Realm, eighteen specks of dust—
If this mind is not pure, it is not true.
To know how hard my realm is to cross,
Ask how many now cross it.

**Third: The Song of the Formless Realm’s Demon King**

Above the Three Realms,
The vast and distant Great Luo.
No root of color above,
Clouds tower in layers.
Only the Primordial Beginning,
The home of kalpas vast,
Governs my realm,
Presiding over the Mysterious Capital.
Those who transgress my realm
Enter the Jade Void.
I, the supreme king,
Rectify and govern the hosts of demons.
Ten thousand transformations in the void,
Defiled qi blooms like flowers.
Few preserve the true,
Many are deluded.
The Dao of immortals is hard to stabilize,
The ghostly path easily turns deviant.
The human path lies in the heart—
Truly, it does not depend on others.
The Dao of immortals values substance,
The human path values splendor.
If you do not delight in the Dao of immortals,
How can you pass the Three Realms?
If you turn to the five paths of desire,
What can I do for you?

From the Heaven of Luminous Courts to the Four Heavens of Elegant Joy is the Primordial Color Realm.
The *Statutes of the Supreme Perfected* says:
In the Formless Realm,
The utmost true are without emotion,
Both color and desire empty,
No longer troubled by form or substance.
When cultivation reaches one heaven,
Only mind and consciousness remain.
Entering the qi-observation,
When qi-observation is perfected,
One ascends to the next heaven.
Again, one can eliminate mind and consciousness,
Attaining non-action,
And ascend further.
If the myriad dharmas reside in the mind,
Whether existent or non-existent,
One ascends again.
If qi-observation becomes wondrous,
All habitual tendencies forgotten,
Merging with the natural,
One ascends to the Heaven of Seed People.

The *Sutra of the Fundamental Limit* says:
Afflictions are knots,
Learning and practice are habits.
When knots and habits are exhausted,
One transcends the rank of seed people,
Merges with the Dao’s realm,
And rises or falls with the qi,
Beyond the reach of calamity.

Master Qingyuan of the Azure Origin says:
Though in the Formless Realm one can leave defilement and forget color,
One still cannot dispel forgetfulness,
And mind and consciousness remain a trouble.
Thus defiled qi blooms like flowers,
And the ghostly path easily turns deviant.
If control is momentarily lost,
One falls into the Realm of Color.
One must forget the mind,
Naturally dispel and observe emptiness to enter the wondrous.

The *Scripture of Lord Lao* says:
What is empty is already non-existent,
Even non-existence is non-existent.
Profoundly and constantly quiescent—
Only then is it true stillness.

Formerly, the Immortal Liu Changsheng of the Prodigal Son
Spent three years in Luoyang,
Daily observing emptiness and dispelling forgetfulness.
When the root of attachment stirred,
He would recite:
“The Northern Capital, Spring-Curved Prefecture,
Holds a host of ten thousand ghosts.
They only desire to cut short one’s destiny,
Sever the gate of life.”
Reciting this song,
The root of attachment was suddenly severed.
Is this not the adept singing the cavernous chapters
To subdue the Northern Feng?

This is true and solid work—
What the Dao of immortals values as substance.
The world is all infatuated,
Not delighting in the Dao of immortals.
Turning the wheel of the five sufferings,
What skill can one employ?
What can be done?

A hymn says:
In the heavens of the Formless Realm, so much grinding and nothingness—
This time, let your mind not be muddled.
These are not idle flowers and grasses,
But the true body entering the Jade Void.

Above the Three Realms,
In the midst of soaring through the void,
The demon kings’ songs,
Their melodies interwoven with the cavernous chapters.

chunks.original_text: 诵之百徧，名度南官； 诵之千徧，魔王保迎； 万徧道备，飞升太空。 过度三界，位登仙公。 有闻灵音，魔王敬形，勅制地祇，侍卫送迎。 拔出地户，五苦八难，七祖升迁，永离鬼宫，魂度朱陵，受炼更生，是谓无量，普度无穷。 有秘上天文，诸天共所崇。 泄慢堕地狱，祸及七祖翁。 三界之上，无非魔王之所居； 飞空之中，徧歌谣章，以魔试，能裨妙道，故参洞章。 夫天尊说诵经，晓世人以行道，诵之百徧，犹梵炁之初回，是云名度南宫。 诵之千徧，犹胎婴之已结，故云魔王保迎。 万徧道备，脱胎神化，故云飞升太空。 此谓道备，若不修道，只诵万徧，以望飞升者，亦难矣。 经功圆成，遇度三界，还丹行满，位登仙公。 有闻灵音，万劫一过，魔王敬形，道高德重。 制地只，勅乃梵炁，地即戊土流戊就巳，返本还元。 拔出地户，阴消阳长，五苦八难，超五行数，除八识根，永离鬼官，阴绝坤户，魂度朱陵，阳聚离宫。 有秘上天文，凡学道之人，睹经则宝爱而珍藏，还丹则潜修而密练，是谓之秘，诸天共所崇，丹道与经皆圆，诸天共所崇仰。 何谓泄慢。 轻易妄为，有闻而不行，或行而不秘，皆受泄慢之祸，恐堕地狱之中。 至於祸及祖翁，即是丧尽元炁，却怨丹经妄语； 又谓太上空言，宁不回思自己妄为泄慢之过也。 颂曰：何故谣章参洞章，只缘地狱与天堂。 尽知地狱惟心造，好向天堂做一场。 道言：此二章并是诸天上帝及至灵魔王隐秘之音，皆是大梵之言，非世上常辞。 言无韵丽，曲无华宛，故谓玄奥，难可寻详。 上天所宝，秘於玄都紫微上宫，依玄科四万劫一传。 若有至人赍金宝质心，依旧格告盟十天，然后而付焉。 上阳子曰：此经冠于诸经者，首尾相应，前后相随故也。 如上卷乃天真皇人笔录玉晨，道君序述元始天尊之说，而万世之下得此经诵之者，犹如当时亲睹其事，斯为妙也。 本章、玉历二章，为正经。 三界魔王歌章，接于二章之后，不属正经。 以其文魔试学人之功为多，故参于元洞之末，是云音参洞章也。 此下则天真皇人又迷道君之言耳。 此二章即混洞赤文、元洞玉历二章。 混洞赤文，明先天元始玄一之还丹； 元洞玉历，明后天无为至真之妙道。 言此二章，独掌不鸣，并是诸天上帝，无非一阴一阳。 至灵魔王，全资神用，隐秘之音，玄关一窍。 大梵之言，铅银砂汞，在经则为诸天帝魔之隐秘，在丹则为玄牝刀圭之梵言，非世上常辞。 世上愚人开口谈道，且不知道为何物，亦不知物为何用，此谓非世上常辞也。 言无韵丽，信言不美，曲无华宛，华则不实，故谓玄奥。 颜闵虽慧莫猜，难可寻详； 黄老无师难悟，上天所宝。 首经而已秘于天宫，非世常用； 四万劫一传，非人不可授。 至人者，乃至圣之人也。 金宝质心，以财易法。 夫金与宝，世之所重。 愚人以金宝为命，胜人以功名为命，义士以名节为命，至人以道德为命。 故至人炼金液九还神丹，乃假金宝以为法财，有法无财，事鲜克济。 有财无法，即同愚人。 经法流通，法财两用，依格告盟，方可付； 强为妄作，事难全。 此道用之说也。 若论世法，则未见以金宝为质信而请经一卷者，更四万劫，亦莫之有。 何以故？ 彼安知是经有长生久视之道焉。
chunks.translated_text:
Reciting it a hundred times, one crosses the Southern Palace;
A thousand times, demon kings come to safeguard and welcome;
Ten thousand times, the Way is complete—ascending to fly through the Great Void.
Passing beyond the Three Realms,
One’s rank attains that of an immortal lord.

Hearing the numinous sound,
Demon kings show reverence in form,
Commanding earth spirits to attend and escort.
Drawn forth from the earthly gate,
The five sufferings and eight hardships are overcome.
Seven generations of ancestors ascend,
Forever departing the demonic palace.
The soul crosses Crimson Mound,
Refined and reborn—
This is called boundless,
Universally delivering the limitless.

There are secret celestial texts,
Revered by all heavens.
To leak or slight them is to fall into hell,
Bringing calamity upon seven generations of ancestors.

Above the Three Realms,
There is nothing not inhabited by demon kings.
Amidst flight through the void,
Everywhere songs and hymns resound—
Demons test one’s resolve,
Yet they may aid the wondrous Way,
Thus interweaving with the cavernous chapters.

The Heavenly Worthy expounded the recitation of scriptures,
Enlightening worldly people to practice the Way.
Reciting it a hundred times
Is like the first return of primordial qi—
Thus it is called crossing the Southern Palace.
A thousand times
Is like the formation of the fetal embryo—
Thus demon kings safeguard and welcome.
Ten thousand times, the Way is complete,
The embryo transforms and the spirit departs—
Thus one flies and ascends to the Great Void.

This is called the completion of the Way.
Without cultivating the Way,
Merely reciting it ten thousand times in hope of ascension
Would be difficult indeed.
When the merit of scripture is perfected,
One crosses the Three Realms;
When the elixir’s work is fulfilled,
One’s rank attains that of an immortal lord.

Hearing the numinous sound—
Once in ten thousand kalpas—
Demon kings show reverence in form,
For the Way is lofty and virtue profound.
Commanding earth spirits
Is the decree of primordial qi.
Earth is the flowing *wu* of *wu* merging with *si*,
Returning to the root and restoring the origin.
Drawn forth from the earthly gate,
Yin dissolves and yang grows.
The five sufferings and eight hardships
Transcend the reckoning of the five phases,
Uprooting the eight consciousnesses’ roots.
Forever departing the demonic palace,
Yin severs the gate of *kun*,
The soul crosses Crimson Mound,
Yang gathers in the palace of *li*.

There are secret celestial texts.
For those who study the Way,
Beholding the scriptures, they treasure and cherish them;
Refining the elixir, they cultivate in seclusion and secrecy.
This is called "secret."
Revered by all heavens,
When the elixir’s Way and the scriptures are both complete,
All heavens revere and look up to them.

What is meant by "leaking and slighting"?
To act carelessly and recklessly,
Hearing but not practicing,
Or practicing without secrecy—
All incur the calamity of leaking and slighting,
Fearing a fall into hell.
As for bringing calamity upon ancestors,
This is to exhaust one’s primordial qi,
Then blame the alchemical scriptures as false,
Or call the Most High’s words empty—
Would they not reflect upon their own fault in leaking and slighting?

A hymn says:
Why do hymns interweave with cavernous chapters?
Only because of hell and heaven.
Knowing that hell is created by the mind alone,
One should strive toward heaven in earnest.

The Dao says:
These two chapters are the hidden sounds of the Celestial Thearchs and the most numinous demon kings,
All words of the Great Brahma,
Not common speech of the world.
Their language lacks ornate beauty,
Their melodies lack florid embellishment—
Thus they are called profound and obscure,
Difficult to fathom in detail.

Treasured by heaven,
They are secreted in the Purple Tenuity’s Upper Palace of the Dark Capital,
Transmitted once every forty thousand kalpas according to the Mysterious Statutes.
If a perfected person pledges gold and treasures with sincerity,
Following the old protocols to swear oaths before the Ten Heavens,
Only then are they entrusted.

Master Shangyang said:
This scripture crowns all others,
For its beginning and end correspond,
Its front and back follow in sequence.
As in the upper scroll,
The Heavenly Perfected One recorded the Jade Dawn,
The Dao Lord narrated the words of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy—
That ten thousand generations later,
Those who recite this scripture
Are as if personally witnessing the events of that time.
This is its wonder.

The present chapter and the *Jade Calendar* are the main scriptures.
The demon kings’ songs of the Three Realms,
Appended after these two chapters,
Do not belong to the main scriptures.
Yet because their texts test the practitioner’s merit extensively,
They are interwoven at the end of the *Primal Cavern*—
Thus called "sounds interweaving with cavernous chapters."
What follows are the Heavenly Perfected One’s further transmissions of the Dao Lord’s words.

These two chapters are the *Crimson Text of the Chaotic Cavern* and the *Jade Calendar of the Primal Cavern*.
The *Crimson Text of the Chaotic Cavern* clarifies the returning elixir of the primordial, original, and mysterious One;
The *Jade Calendar of the Primal Cavern* clarifies the wondrous Way of the posterior, effortless, and perfectly true.
These two chapters,
Unique and unparalleled,
Are the hidden sounds of all Celestial Thearchs—
Nothing but the interplay of yin and yang.
The most numinous demon kings
Fully rely on spiritual efficacy,
Their hidden sounds the mysterious pass of the One Aperture.
The words of the Great Brahma—
Lead, silver, cinnabar, mercury—
In scripture, they are the hidden secrets of the Celestial Thearchs and demon kings;
In the elixir, they are the Brahma-words of the Mysterious Female’s knife and measure,
Not common speech of the world.

Foolish people of the world open their mouths to discuss the Way,
Yet do not know what the Way is,
Nor what its substances are for—
This is called "not common speech of the world."
Their language lacks ornate beauty—
True words are not embellished;
Their melodies lack florid embellishment—
Flourish is not substance.
Thus they are called profound and obscure.
Though Yan and Min were wise, they could not guess;
Though Huang and Lao had no teacher, they could not comprehend—
Treasured by heaven.
The first scripture alone is secreted in the celestial palace,
Not commonly used in the world.
Transmitted once every forty thousand kalpas,
It is not to be given to just anyone.
The "perfected person" is one of utmost sageliness.
Pledging gold and treasures is exchanging wealth for the Dharma.

Gold and treasures are what the world values.
Foolish people take gold and treasures as their lives;
Petty men take fame and rank as their lives;
Righteous scholars take reputation and integrity as their lives;
Perfected persons take virtue and the Way as their lives.
Thus perfected persons refine the nine-return divine elixir of golden liquid,
Using gold and treasures as Dharma-wealth.
With Dharma but no wealth, matters seldom succeed;
With wealth but no Dharma, one is no different from a fool.
When scriptures circulate,
Dharma and wealth are both employed.
Following the protocols to swear oaths,
Only then may they be entrusted.
To act presumptuously and recklessly is difficult to complete.
This is the explanation of its use in the Way.

As for worldly matters,
One has never seen someone pledge gold and treasures as earnest money to request a scroll of scripture—
Even in forty thousand kalpas, none would exist.
Why?
How would they know this scripture contains the Way of long life and enduring vision?

In the heavens of the Formless Realm, so much grinding and nothingness—

chunks.original_text: 若言道用，犹或有之，何以故？ 彼上根法器之士，宿命因缘，於丹经内默有所得，未能深达玄旨，忽闻此经妙谛，叉赍金宝信受不疑。 夫九还七返之方，叉外药而合内药，若非金宝为质，则安能得此经之妙，又安能伏虎以降龙，又安能得先天之炁自虚无中来也。 凡今之世，愚夫浊子一闻法财，必为大笑，便谓修行者，要彻骨贫、一丝不挂，只从事顽坐，流于空寂渀荡。 此辇直赚到老，安知斋金宝以求妙经。 是法财两用之旨。 希夷真人《入室诗》曰：入室何独异，金花日日开。 灵苗从地出，香药向天来。 又云：欲慕天中宝，应须动世财。 蓬莱瑶洞裹，酝就九还桮。 王鼎真人曰：凡俗欲求天上事，寻时须用世间财。 盖天中宝、天上事、是仙家密密运用之机，却非傍门探取之谬。 伐瑳迷伽承师教已，问：云何为报？ 师曰：若办五百羯利沙钵那者，足表深心。 尔时迷伽遍地寻觅，既具集已，即呈偈曰：饶财多宝珍，春属具成就。 必定於菩提，常安住於法。 夫伐瑳迷伽为天人师留此一偈，与后来人证道作佛之眼目，非同外道邪魔之行。 谛观斯语，则此经必金宝质心而后付，方得其妙。 颂曰：一些财利不关心，金宝何为度得人。 我是青城亲付属，还丹只要虎龙亲。 元始无量度人上品妙经注解卷中竟 #1「上元」二字原缺，据后文例补。 #2 化化：应作「他化」。 佛经有他化自天。 太上洞玄灵宝元始无量度人上品妙经解注卷下 上阳子陈观吾注 道言：夫天地运度，亦有否终； 日月五星，亦有亏盈； 至圣神人，亦有休否； 末学之夫，亦有疾伤。

If one speaks of the application of the Dao, such cases may yet exist. Why? Those of superior roots and proper Dharma-vessels, by virtue of karmic affinities from past lives, have already gained some understanding within the alchemical scriptures. Though they may not yet fully grasp the profound essence, upon suddenly hearing the sublime truths of this sutra, they offer gold and treasures in unwavering faith.

The methods of nine-return and seven-reversion require the external medicine to merge with the internal medicine. Without gold and treasures as earnest, how could one obtain the wonders of this sutra? How could one subdue the tiger to descend the dragon? How could one draw the primordial qi from the midst of emptiness?

In this present age, when foolish and impure men hear of Dharma-wealth, they invariably burst into laughter, claiming that cultivators must be utterly destitute, stripped bare, and devoted solely to rigid sitting, drifting into hollow stillness. Such people toil in vain until old age, never understanding the use of gold and treasures to seek the wondrous sutra. This is the principle of employing both Dharma and wealth.

The Perfected of Mystery and Silence’s *Entering the Chamber Poem* says:
*Entering the chamber, what makes it unique?*
*Golden flowers bloom day after day.*
*The numinous sprout rises from the earth,*
*Fragrant medicine descends from the heavens.*

It also states:
*To yearn for the treasure of heaven,*
*One must first move worldly wealth.*
*Within the jade caves of Penglai,*
*The nine-returned cup is brewed.*

The Perfected Wang Ding says:
*If mortals seek the affairs of heaven,*
*They must first use the wealth of the world.*
For the treasure of heaven and the affairs of heaven are the subtle mechanisms of immortals’ practice—far removed from the deluded grasping of heterodox paths.

When Faduo Migajia received the master’s teaching, he asked, “How should one repay?”
The master replied, “If you prepare five hundred *kārṣāpaṇa*, it will fully express your profound sincerity.”
Thereupon, Migajia searched the earth, and having gathered them, presented this verse:
*Abundant wealth, many treasures,*
*Spring’s attributes all fulfilled.*
*Certain of bodhi,*
*Ever abiding in the Dharma.*

This verse left by Faduo Migajia, the teacher of gods and men, serves as the eye and guide for later generations to realize the Dao and attain Buddhahood—unlike the practices of heretical demons. Carefully observing these words, one sees that this sutra must be entrusted only after pledging gold and treasures with sincerity, thereby attaining its wonders.

The ode says:
*Unmoved by even a speck of wealth,*
*How can gold and treasures ferry others?*
*I, of Qingcheng, was personally entrusted,*
*For the elixir of return, only the tiger and dragon suffice.*

**End of the Middle Scroll of the *Commentary on the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of the Primordial Limitless Salvation of Beings*, Upper Chapter**

**The Lower Scroll of the *Explanatory Commentary on the Supreme and Wondrous Scripture of the Primordial Limitless Salvation of Beings from the Numinous Treasure of the Cavernous Mystery***
*Commentary by Chen Guanzhen of Shangyang*

The Dao says:
The revolutions of heaven and earth also have their ends;
The sun, moon, and five planets also wax and wane;
Even the most sagely and divine persons also have their limits;
And the ignorant and unlearned also suffer illness and harm.

chunks.original_text: 凡有此灾，同炁皆当齐心修斋，六时行香，十遍转经，福德立降，消诸不祥。 无量之文，普度无穷。 上阳子曰：天地运度，以道用言，则人之身得天地正中之炁。 头像天，足像地，故曰人身一小天地。 夫天地之造化，生人生物； 而人身之造化，生佛生仙。 《灵宝毕法》曰：道生万物，天地乃物中之大者，人为物中之灵者。 别求於道，人同天地，心比天，肾比地，肝为阳，肺为阴，一上一下，仰观俯察，可以赜其机； 一始一终，度数筹算，可以得其理。 《易》曰：天尊地卑，乾坤定矣。 《老子》曰：有物混成，先天地生，吾不知其名，强名之曰道。 张真人曰：甘露降时天地合，黄芽生处坎离交。 先把乾坤为鼎器，次搏乌兔药来烹。 故金丹以天地为鼎器也。 世法则天地运度，古人以一大为天。 经云：域中有四大； 道大，天大，地大，王亦大。 浑天论天，如鸡子，地如中黄，大地在天体之内。 天之南北，两极如门枢轮轴。 天旋一昼夜，而周两极，不离元所。 其谓天如鸡子者，鸡子形不正圆，古人知天形相肖，故以比之。 但喻地在天内，天包地外而已。 缘督子曰：天如绣球，内盛半球水，水上浮一板，板比大地。 板上置诸物，比人品万类； 球常旋转，板上诸物未尝觉知。 天乃日夜旋转，地居其中，人物在于地上，安然不动，此球浮板之喻，切几之矣。 浑天论地在天体之内者，天非可见其体，因众星出没东西，管辖于两极，有常度，无停机，遂即星所附丽，拟为天之体耳。 《革象》云：天体圆如弹丸，圆体中心，六合之的也。 周围上下，相矩正等，名曰天中。 天中直上至于天顶，古者测景于阳城，得天顶正中之景。 仰观北极，出地入地，并三十六度，是为天中而非地中。 若论地维，四方之中，当以四海之至而求。 黄河之源为昆仑，是大地最高处。 西番指为闷母黎山，水分四向而流，其山距东海不满二万里，距西海三万余里。 阳城距东海近，而距昆仑远，天下之地多西，昆仑尚在东土。 要知大地之中，乃在昆仑之西也。 浑天比天如鸡子者，中黄为地，是地上天少，地下天多。 《革象》乃云：地上天多，地下天少。 亦为有理。 若论天之高下，《玉书》云：天地之间，上下相去八万四千里，气质不能相交。 天以乾索於坤而还於地中，其阳负阴而升； 地以坤索於乾而还於天中，其阴抱阳而降； 升降而运於道。 《三五历纪》曰：天地开辟，阳清为天，阴浊为地。 盘古生于中，神於天、圣於地； 天极高，地极深，盘古极长。 后有三皇，数起乎一、立於三、成於五、盛於七、处於九，故天去地九万里。 两说相同，则知地上至天九万里，地下亦九万里，是天之体中高十八万里。 古以三百六十步为一里，如前本章化生诸天所注几百几十万里者，非实有其数。 比上根之士能绝欲乐，即同圣贤，与彼下界之人相隔远甚也。 如此又如地之宽阔，自东海滨之西，至西海滨之东，五万余里。 海之阔，又三万里，海之外，二万里，则极东至极西，通十五万里，径与十八万里之高，则浑天谓形如鸡子者是矣。 天道左运周天三百六十五度，余四之一，每昼夜一周遭，无有穷已。 刘宋祖冲之善观天文，见极星去不动。 处一度余，盖历家测北极而知度数长短。
chunks.translated_text:
For all such calamities, those of shared qi must unite in heart to perform purification rites, burn incense in the six periods, and recite the scripture ten times—whereupon virtue and power will descend at once, dissolving all inauspicious omens. The boundless text universally delivers the limitless.

Master Shangyang says: When the revolutions of heaven and earth are spoken of in terms of the Dao, then the human body receives the central qi of heaven and earth. The head resembles heaven, the feet resemble earth—thus the human body is called a small heaven and earth. The transformations of heaven and earth give birth to humans and all beings; the transformations of the human body give birth to buddhas and immortals.

The *Lingbao Complete Methods* states: The Dao gives birth to the myriad things. Among them, heaven and earth are the greatest, and humans are the most numinous. If one seeks the Dao separately, humans are equal to heaven and earth. The heart corresponds to heaven, the kidneys to earth; the liver is yang, the lungs are yin. Rising and falling, gazing upward and downward, one may fathom their mechanism. Beginning and ending, measuring and calculating, one may grasp their principle.

The *Book of Changes* says: Heaven is noble, earth is lowly—thus Qian and Kun are established.
The *Laozi* says: There is a thing formed in chaos, born before heaven and earth. I know not its name, so I style it the Dao.

Master Zhang the Perfected says:
When sweet dew descends, heaven and earth unite;
Where the yellow sprout arises, Kan and Li merge.
First take Qian and Kun as the crucible and vessel,
Then gather the crow and hare to refine the medicine.

Thus, the golden elixir uses heaven and earth as its crucible and vessel.

In worldly reckoning, the revolutions of heaven and earth are vast—ancients took the great unity as heaven. The scripture says: Within the realm are four great things: the Dao is great, heaven is great, earth is great, and the king is also great.

The *Huntian Theory* likens heaven to an egg, with earth like the yolk within. The great earth lies within the body of heaven. The north and south poles of heaven are like the pivot and axle of a wheel. Heaven rotates once in a day and night, circling the two poles without leaving its original place. The comparison of heaven to an egg refers to its imperfectly round shape—ancients knew the resemblance of its form and thus used it as an analogy. It merely illustrates that earth lies within heaven, and heaven envelops earth.

Master Yuanduzi says: Heaven is like a brocade ball, containing a half-sphere of water. Upon the water floats a board, which represents the great earth. The objects placed on the board represent the myriad kinds of humans. The ball constantly rotates, yet the objects on the board remain unaware. Heaven rotates day and night, while earth abides within it. Humans and beings upon the earth remain unmoving—this analogy of the floating board is most apt.

The *Huntian Theory*’s claim that earth lies within the body of heaven does not mean heaven’s body is visible. Rather, observing the rising and setting of the stars in the east and west, governed by the two poles with fixed degrees and no cessation, one infers the stars’ attachment and posits it as the body of heaven.

The *Gexiang* states: The body of heaven is round like a pellet, and the center of this round body is the target of the six directions. All around, above and below, it is square and equal—this is called the center of heaven. The center of heaven extends straight upward to the zenith. In ancient times, measuring shadows at Yangcheng yielded the shadow of the zenith’s exact center. Gazing upward at the North Pole, its emergence and submergence above and below the earth total thirty-six degrees—this is the center of heaven, not the center of earth. As for the earth’s axis, the center of the four directions should be sought at the farthest reaches of the four seas. The source of the Yellow River is Kunlun, the highest place on earth. The Western Barbarians call it Mount Memuli, from which waters flow in four directions. The mountain lies less than twenty thousand *li* from the Eastern Sea and over thirty thousand *li* from the Western Sea. Yangcheng is closer to the Eastern Sea but farther from Kunlun. Most of the world’s land lies to the west, yet Kunlun still stands in the eastern lands. One must know that the true center of the great earth lies west of Kunlun.

The *Huntian*’s comparison of heaven to an egg, with the yolk as earth, implies less heaven above earth and more below. The *Gexiang* claims the opposite—more heaven above earth and less below—which also has its logic.

Regarding the height of heaven, the *Jade Book* says: Between heaven and earth, the distance above and below is eighty-four thousand *li*, and their qi and substance cannot interact. Heaven seeks Qian from Kun and returns to the center of earth, its yang bearing yin upward. Earth seeks Kun from Qian and returns to the center of heaven, its yin embracing yang downward. Rising and falling, they revolve within the Dao.

The *Sanwu Liji* states: When heaven and earth opened, the clear yang became heaven, and the turbid yin became earth. Pangu was born between them, divine in heaven and sagely on earth. Heaven is extremely high, earth extremely deep, and Pangu extremely tall. Later came the Three Sovereigns, whose numbers began with one, stood upon three, were completed by five, flourished in seven, and resided in nine—thus heaven is ninety thousand *li* from earth.

Both accounts agree: from earth to heaven is ninety thousand *li*, and from earth below to heaven is also ninety thousand *li*—thus the body of heaven is one hundred eighty thousand *li* in height. Anciently, three hundred sixty paces made one *li*. As in previous chapters’ notes on the generation of the various heavens, the hundreds of thousands of *li* mentioned are not literal. They signify that those of superior roots who cut off desire and joy become equal to sages and worthies, far removed from the people of the lower realms.

Similarly, the breadth of the earth: from the eastern shore of the Eastern Sea to the western shore of the Western Sea is over fifty thousand *li*. The width of the seas is another thirty thousand *li*, and beyond the seas, twenty thousand *li*—thus from the farthest east to the farthest west spans one hundred fifty thousand *li*. Compared to the height of one hundred eighty thousand *li*, the *Huntian*’s likening of its shape to an egg is apt.

The Dao of heaven rotates left, circling the three hundred sixty-five and a quarter degrees of the celestial sphere once each day and night, without end. During the Liu Song dynasty, Zu Chongzhi, skilled in observing the heavens, saw that the Pole Star remained nearly motionless, deviating by just over one degree. Thus, astronomers measuring the North Pole determined the length of degrees.

chunks.original_text: 《郭守敬行状》：至元十六年，守敬奏，唐一行开元间，令南宫说天下测景。 今疆宇比唐尤大，若不远方测验日月交食，分数时刻不同，昼夜长短不同，日月星辰、去天高下不同，即目测验人少，可先南北立表，取直余里，是天每度有一千三百九十里，而月之度却窄於日之径。 月一度止得六百七十里，周三百六十五度，余止计二十四万里，是月近於人，天最远於人。 唯日得其中道，故凡历测，皆以日为主而作准则也。 日行之道，定二十八宿之名。 唐虞之际，冬至日躔虚宿。 何以知其然？ 在《尧典》曰：日短星昴，以正仲冬。 且冬至日短，日入申末，昴星见酉。 初时而在南方午上，太阳却在酉方，虚属天盘子。 以天盘子加临地盘酉，子加酉，则酉叉加午。 昴属天盘酉，而冬至见地盘午。 故冬至太阳躔虚，夏至躔星，春分在昴，秋分在房。 古者唯以夜半中星孜其日度，是以容成造历，车区占星是也。 汉作《太初历》：仲冬日在丑躔牵牛。 初尧至汉差一宫。 晋虞喜谓五十年差一度，何承天谓百年差一度，随刘焯以七十五年差一度，唐一行八十三年差一度。 《大衍历》：日在斗十三度。 宋乃以焯七十五年为准。 至元十四年，丁丑，冬至，日躔箕十度。 至元三年丁丑日躔箕八度。 则尧时日在子，汉时日在丑。 金宋之间，日在寅。 自尧至今，三千七百年，日已差三宫。 则尧之后，九千余年，日反躔午； 一万八千余年，日复躔子。 是帝尧之前，亦必如此。 故李淳风以古历章蔀纪元，分度不齐，始为总法。 一行以朔有四大三小，定九服交食之异。 徐昴以日食有气，刻时三差。 姚舜辅知食甚泛，余差数革象，谓上古岁差少，后世岁差多。 以唐宋到今验之，果符其说也。 古人以三百六十时有余，均作二气六候，为一月。 然每月朔，止得三百五十六个时令三刻有奇。 而一气则十五日有余。 故月大曰气盈，月小曰亏，名为朔虚。 此谓汨月五星，亦有亏盈，非但指日月晦食为亏盈也。 又如五星，亦因日而有迟留伏逆近日则疾，远日则迟。 迟甚而留，留久而退，初迟退，渐疾退，退最疾而复迟退。 如初退止而留，留久而顺行最疾，则与太阳同躔。 岁星最疾，四日行一度； 荧惑最疾，七日行五度； 镇星最疾，七日行一度。 此三星比太阳行度较少，故伏合以后，太阳在前，岁星距日十三度而晨见，荧惑距日十九度而晨见，镇星距日十八度半而晨见。 大约近一远二而留，周天相半而退。 岁星初留，约距日一百九度； 初退，距日一百三十一度。 荧惑初留，距日一百三十四度； 初退，亦然。 镇星初留，距日九十四度； 初退，距日一百二十八度。 凡退行，最疾之时，叉与太阳对冲，退止而留、留久而顺行。 太白最疾，约四日行五度； 辰星最疾，一日行二度。 太白距日远，不出四十度； 辰星距日远，不出二十四度。 距日远则行迟，距日近则行疾。 金木形体大，故伏见与日近； 水火土形体小，故伏见与日远。 此五星之常数也。 至圣神人，亦有休否。 夫舜有井廪之虑，文王有羑里之囚，周公居东二年，孔子厄於陈蔡，老君化胡而为所难，如来割肉以与贼徒，岂非至圣神人亦有休否者乎！ 末学之夫，亦有疾伤； 士之学道，而不动行，是为末学之夫。

**The Record of Guo Shoujing’s Conduct:**

In the sixteenth year of the Zhiyuan era (1279), Guo Shoujing memorialized: During the Kaiyuan reign of the Tang, Yi Xing ordered Nan Gongshuo to conduct nationwide solar shadow measurements. Today, our empire surpasses the Tang in vastness. Without distant observations to verify solar and lunar eclipses, discrepancies arise in their magnitudes and timings, as well as in the varying lengths of day and night, and the differing altitudes of the sun, moon, and stars. Given the scarcity of observers, we may first erect gnomons north and south, aligning them over great distances. Thus, each celestial degree spans 1,390 *li*, while the moon’s path is narrower than the sun’s diameter—each lunar degree measures only 670 *li*. A full circuit of 365 degrees totals no more than 240,000 *li*, proving the moon is nearer to man, and heaven most distant. Only the sun traverses the middle Way, so all calendrical calculations take it as their standard.

The sun’s path defines the names of the twenty-eight lodges. During the reigns of Yao and Shun, the winter solstice sun lodged in *Xu*. How do we know? The *Canon of Yao* states: “The shortest day, the star *Mao* [Pleiades], marks mid-winter.” At winter solstice, the day is shortest; the sun sets at the end of *Shen*, and *Mao* appears in *You*. Initially, *Mao* stands due south at *Wu*, while the sun lies in *You*. *Xu* belongs to the celestial *Zi* (north). When the celestial *Zi* aligns with the earthly *You*, *Zi* overlays *You*, and *You* in turn overlays *Wu*. *Mao* belongs to the celestial *You*, yet at winter solstice, it appears in the earthly *Wu*. Thus, the winter solstice sun lodges in *Xu*, the summer solstice in *Xing*, the spring equinox in *Mao*, and the autumn equinox in *Fang*. Ancient astronomers determined the sun’s degrees solely by the midnight culmination of stars—hence the calendars devised by Rong Cheng and the stellar divinations of Che Qu.

The *Taichu* calendar of the Han placed the mid-winter sun in *Chou*, lodging in *Qianniu*. From Yao to the Han, the lodging shifted by one mansion. Yu Xi of the Jin estimated a shift of one degree every fifty years; He Chengtian, one degree per century; Liu Zhuo, one degree every seventy-five years; and Yi Xing of the Tang, one degree every eighty-three years. The *Dayan* calendar placed the sun at thirteen degrees in *Dou*. The Song adopted Liu Zhuo’s seventy-five-year standard. In the fourteenth year of the Zhiyuan era (1277), on the *dingchou* day of the winter solstice, the sun lodged at ten degrees in *Ji*. In the third year of the Zhiyuan era (1266), on the *dingchou* day, it lodged at eight degrees in *Ji*. Thus, in Yao’s time, the sun was in *Zi*; in the Han, in *Chou*; and between the Jin and Song, in *Yin*. From Yao to the present—3,700 years—the sun has shifted three mansions. Extrapolating, nine thousand years hence, the sun will lodge in *Wu*; eighteen thousand years hence, it will return to *Zi*. Before Yao’s time, the pattern must have been the same. Hence, Li Chunfeng, finding ancient calendars’ cycles and epochs inconsistent in their divisions, established a unified method. Yi Xing, noting four long and three short months in the lunar cycle, determined regional variations in eclipses. Xu Mao accounted for solar eclipses’ qi, refining the three temporal discrepancies. Yao Shunfu recognized the approximate nature of eclipse maxima, attributing the changing residual discrepancies to celestial images, and noted that precession was slower in high antiquity and faster in later ages. Observations from the Tang and Song to the present confirm his theory.

Ancients divided the 360-odd hours of a year into twelve qi and seventy-two hou, forming a month. Yet each month’s new moon spans only 356 hours and a fraction. A single qi exceeds fifteen days. Thus, long months are called “qi surplus,” short months “deficient,” and the new moon “void.” This refers not only to the waxing and waning of the sun and moon at conjunction and eclipse but also to the five planets’ cyclical fluctuations. The five planets, too, vary in speed relative to the sun: near the sun, they move swiftly; far, slowly. When slowest, they pause; after lingering, they retreat. Initially retreating slowly, they gradually accelerate, then slow again. When retreat halts, they pause, then resume direct motion at their swiftest, aligning with the sun’s path.

Jupiter moves fastest at one degree every four days; Mars, five degrees in seven days; Saturn, one degree in seven days. These three planets’ speeds are slower than the sun’s, so after conjunction, the sun leads them: Jupiter appears at dawn when thirteen degrees from the sun, Mars at nineteen degrees, and Saturn at eighteen and a half degrees. Generally, they pause once near and twice far, then retreat halfway through their celestial circuit. Jupiter first pauses at 109 degrees from the sun; first retreats at 131 degrees. Mars first pauses at 134 degrees; first retreats likewise. Saturn first pauses at 94 degrees; first retreats at 128 degrees. During their fastest retrograde motion, they oppose the sun. Retrogression ceases, they pause, then resume direct motion.

Venus moves fastest at five degrees in four days; Mercury, two degrees in one day. Venus does not exceed forty degrees from the sun; Mercury, twenty-four degrees. Far from the sun, they move slowly; near, swiftly. Jupiter and Mars, being large, appear near the sun; Saturn, Venus, and Mercury, being small, appear farther. These are the five planets’ constant measures.

Even the most sagely and divine may know adversity. Shun faced peril at the well and granary; King Wen was imprisoned at Youli; the Duke of Zhou resided in the east for two years; Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai; Laozi was challenged while transforming the Hu; the Tathāgata carved his flesh for bandits. Are not even the sagest and most divine subject to fortune’s vicissitudes? Likewise, lesser scholars may suffer affliction. Those who study the Dao yet fail to act are but shallow learners.

chunks.original_text: 不勤则道不成，道不成，则疾患至矣。 凡有此灾，同气皆当齐心修斋，六时行香，十遍转经，同气即同类也。 既同其类，必能齐心，其心若齐，方能办事。 世人知看经而不知转经，看经者求福，转经者求丹，经圆福至，丹成德重。 故云福德立降。 此经多言无量之文，普度无穷者，意在经而主乎丹也。 夫元始梵炁，还丹之道，上根至士，下及至愚，小人但能信受而行，皆跻圣位。 故云普度无穷。 颂曰：有形有数有终穷，直到无形体太空。 若问无形何所似，全身放在黍珠中。 道言：夫末学道浅，或仙品未充，运应灭度，身经太阴，临过之时，同学至人为其行香诵经十过，以度尸形如法，魂神径上南宫，随其学功计日而得更生，转轮不灭，便得神仙。 上阳子曰：此为下士晚闻道者言也。 夫末学道浅，仙品未充，修学之人，不能勇猛勤行，而复年当迟暮，精气已衰，不觉腊月三十夜到来，无可奈何，遂行夺舍投胎之法。 盖夺舍与投胎，乃是两事。 此法虽属傍门，然得之者亦可以度其尸形，使真性不落于轮回也。 若五祖之投周氏胎，松精亦投金公室是也。 故云以度尸形如法。 然必得同学至人为其护卫，则魂神径上南宫。 如四祖之题五祖，洞宾之度松精，此为同学至人也。 随其学功者，盖修学之士，其功有深有浅，故随其功之深浅，计日之远近，而更生。 虽经转轮而真性不灭，待其金液大丹之道成，是云便得神仙也。 颂曰：计日更生随学功，功圆八百显金容。 大罗天上风流好，信道元来色即空。 道言：夫天地运终，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 星宿错度，日月失昏，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 四时失度，阴阳不调，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 国主有灾，兵革四兴，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 疫毒流行，兆民死伤，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 师友命过，亦当修斋，行香诵经。 夫斋戒诵经，功德甚重，上消天灾，保镇帝王，下禳毒害，以度兆民。 生死受赖，其福难胜。 故曰无量，普度天人。 上阳子曰：天地运终。 以道用释，大修行人以天地而比一身。 还丹若成，功行未积，不能白日飞身，乃厌尘世，或欲示疾而去，或欲蜕形而行，或止得脱壳尸解之道，皆谓之运终。 若直谓天地果然运终，则民生其有几何？ 孰得而修斋行香，又孰得而诵经乎？ 星宿错度，日月失昏。 此乃身中神炁耗散，耳目眩瞶，盖日月五星比人身之七窍也。 《三光经》云：耳若乱听，声色败人； 眼若视恶，真光不明； 鼻若闻臭，玉真不清； 口若杂味，身多病生。 是故病从口入，福从色败； 子若戒之，命同天在。 四时失度，夫真炁乖理，则阴阳不调。 彭真人曰：阳火过刻，水旱不调，凝冬变为大暑也。 阴符失节，寒暖相侵，盛夏反为浓霜也。 金宫既砂汞之不萌，一鼎则虫螟之互起。 大则山崩地圯，金虎与木龙沸腾，小则雨暴风飘，坎男共离女奔逸。 《内义》曰：太上所谓修斋行香诵经者，即虚心炼炁，顺神养真，如上皆道用之谓。 若论世法，天地运终，则欲界六天大劫一交，为火所焚。 色界一十八天，大劫一交，为水所漂。 无色界四天，大劫一交，为风所坏。 此三界坏尽，上帝乃於种民天，选一人下世为民种，故曰种民天。 以此观之，则天地其有运终之时也。

Without diligence, the Dao cannot be accomplished; if the Dao is not accomplished, afflictions and misfortunes will arrive. Whenever such calamities occur, those of shared qi must unite in heart to perform purification rites, burn incense in the six periods, and recite the scriptures ten times—those of shared qi are of the same kind. Being of the same kind, they must unite in heart; only when their hearts are aligned can matters be resolved.

The worldly know how to read scriptures but not how to recite them in cycles. Reading scriptures seeks blessings; reciting them in cycles seeks the elixir. When the scriptures are fully recited, blessings arrive; when the elixir is achieved, virtue is profound. Thus it is said: "Blessings and virtue descend at once." These scriptures speak of boundless words to universally deliver the limitless, yet their intent lies in the scriptures and centers on the elixir.

The primordial Brahma qi is the Way of the Returned Elixir. From the highest-rooted sagely scholars to the lowest and most foolish, if even petty men can believe, accept, and practice it, all may ascend to the sacred rank. Thus it is said: "Universally deliver the limitless."

**Verse:**
Form has number and ends in exhaustion,
Until it reaches formlessness and the great void.
If one asks what formlessness resembles,
The whole body rests within a millet-like pearl.

The Dao states: Those of shallow learning in the Dao, whose immortal rank is not yet fulfilled, when their destined time of passing arrives and their bodies enter the Great Yin, at the moment of transition, fellow students and perfected beings should burn incense and recite the scriptures ten times on their behalf to deliver the corpse according to the method. Then the hun-soul will ascend directly to the Southern Palace, and according to the merit of their studies, they will be reborn after a calculated number of days, escaping the turning wheel of rebirth and attaining immortality.

Master Shangyang said: This speaks of those of lesser attainment who hear the Dao late in life. Those of shallow learning in the Dao, whose immortal rank is not yet fulfilled, who fail to practice with courage and diligence, and whose years are already advanced with waning essence and qi—unaware that the thirtieth night of the twelfth month has arrived—have no recourse but to employ the methods of seizing a vessel or entering a womb. Seizing a vessel and entering a womb are two distinct matters. Though this method belongs to the side gates, those who attain it may still deliver their corpse, ensuring their true nature does not fall into the cycle of rebirth. Such as the Fifth Patriarch entering the womb of the Zhou family, or Song Jing entering the Golden Lord’s household. Thus it is said: "To deliver the corpse according to the method." Yet this requires fellow students and perfected beings to protect and guide them, so the hun-soul may ascend directly to the Southern Palace. Like the Fourth Patriarch inscribing for the Fifth, or Lü Dongbin delivering Song Jing—these are fellow students and perfected beings.

"According to the merit of their studies" means that among those who cultivate and study, merit varies in depth. Thus, according to the depth of their merit, the number of days until rebirth is calculated. Though they pass through the turning wheel, their true nature remains undestroyed. When the Great Elixir of Golden Liquor is achieved, they attain immortality.

**Verse:**
Rebirth is calculated by days according to merit,
When merit is complete at eight hundred, the golden countenance appears.
In the wondrous realm of the Great Luo,
Those who believe in the Dao know form is but emptiness.

The Dao states: When the heavens and earth reach their destined end, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When the stars and constellations fall into disorder and the sun and moon lose their proper times, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When the four seasons lose their proper order and yin and yang fall out of harmony, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When the ruler of the state faces calamity and warfare erupts on all sides, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When pestilence spreads and the people suffer death and injury, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures. When masters and friends pass away, one must perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures.

The merit of purification rites and scripture recitation is profound. Above, it dispels heavenly disasters and safeguards the emperor; below, it wards off poisonous harm and delivers the people. In life and death, all rely upon it—its blessings are beyond measure. Thus it is said: "Boundless, universally delivering gods and humans."

Master Shangyang said: "The heavens and earth reach their destined end." Interpreted through the Dao’s application, great cultivators compare the heavens and earth to the body. If the Returned Elixir is achieved but merit is not accumulated, one cannot ascend bodily in broad daylight. Thus, they may grow weary of the mundane world, choosing to feign illness and depart, shed their form and leave, or merely attain the method of corpse liberation—all are called "reaching their destined end." If taken literally as the heavens and earth truly reaching their end, how many people would remain? Who would perform purification rites, burn incense, or recite scriptures?

"When the stars and constellations fall into disorder and the sun and moon lose their proper times"—this refers to the dissipation of the body’s spirit and qi, causing the ears and eyes to grow dim. The sun, moon, and five planets correspond to the seven orifices of the body. The *Scripture of the Three Luminaries* states: "If the ears listen recklessly, sounds and colors corrupt the person; if the eyes gaze upon evil, the true light dims; if the nose smells foulness, the Jade Perfection is not pure; if the mouth consumes杂味, the body suffers many illnesses. Thus, illness enters through the mouth, and fortune is lost through the senses. If you guard against these, your life will endure like heaven."

"When the four seasons lose their proper order"—if the true qi deviates from principle, yin and yang fall out of harmony. Master Peng said: "If the yang fire exceeds its measure, drought and flood disrupt the seasons, and midwinter turns to scorching heat. If the yin tally loses its rhythm, cold and warmth encroach upon each other, and midsummer brings thick frost. When the Golden Palace fails to sprout cinnabar and mercury, the cauldron breeds insects and pests. In great cases, mountains collapse and the earth splits, the Metal Tiger and Wood Dragon boil over; in minor cases, violent rain and whirlwinds arise, the Kan man and Li woman flee in chaos."

The *Inner Meaning* states: What the Most High calls "performing purification rites, burning incense, and reciting scriptures" refers to refining qi with an empty mind, nurturing the spirit by following its nature, and cultivating the true. All the above are applications of the Dao. In worldly terms, when the heavens and earth reach their destined end, the Six Heavens of the Desire Realm undergo a great kalpa and are consumed by fire. The Eighteen Heavens of the Form Realm undergo a great kalpa and are swept away by water. The Four Heavens of the Formless Realm undergo a great kalpa and are destroyed by wind. When these Three Realms are utterly destroyed, the Lord of Heaven selects one person from the Heaven of Seeded People to descend and repopulate the world—hence it is called the Heaven of Seeded People. From this perspective, the heavens and earth indeed have a time of destined end.

chunks.original_text: 星宿错度，日月失昏，古人仰观天象，见众星昏晓出没，渐渐不同，乃比天体如圆瓜，以瓜有十二瓣，周天三百六十五度余四之一，均作十二分，则一瓣计三十度、四十三分七十五杪，度度皆辐辏於南北极，犹其度敛尖於两端最广处，在瓜之腰围。 瓜腰一围，名曰赤道。 其度在赤道者，正得一度之广，去赤道远者，渐远渐窄，虽有一度之名，实无腰围一度之广。 各度皆以二十八宿之距星纪数，谓之经度。 东西分经、南北分纬，经续皆以二极远近为数。 两极相距一百八十二度六十二分五十杪。 赤道横分，与两极相远，各九十一度三十一分二十五杪。 天顶名嵩高，北极偏於嵩高，而北者五十五度有奇。 南极偏於地中之下而南者，亦五十五度有奇。 赤道则斜倚在嵩高之南三十六度，两傍乃正卯酉之位。 日月星宿不着於天，乃假大化之炁，悬空而行，亦犹鱼之不着於地，乃假水之道而行于江河也。 北齐张子信仰观岁久，知五纬有盈缩之变，遂加常数以求其逐日之躔。 盖五纬不由黄道，亦不由月之九道，乃出入于黄道之内外。 五纬各自有道，视太阳远近而迟疾者，如足力之有勤倦； 又有变数之加灭者，如路里之有曲直。 岁星加灭最多处，七度有余。 荧惑二十五度余，土星八度余，太白四度余，辰星六度余。 罗计气孛所行无迟疾。 罗计从月，交黄道而求月交之．终始； 罗计於其间各逆行一度四十六分三十杪。 月孛从月之盈缩而求。 紫炁，起於闰法。 二十八年十闰，紫炁周十二宫。 紫炁，即景星也。 史注：景星状如半月，凡见则人君有德明圣之庆。 星之留段，是一日绕地一周，与天同过一度。 行疾者反是迟，行迟者反是疾，退者反是疾之甚。 不及天行之数，即所行度，日月相会同经度。 夫日食於朔者，日月同经不同纬，只合朔而不食。 若日月既同经，而月从八道穿度日之黄道而出入。 其时，日亦在彼，即同经而又同纬，则合朔而有食。 说者谓十曜之星，皆能食日者，非也。 日本无食，但一时为月之黑体所蔽阵，世以为食，然日体未尝有损。 其所障有多少者，盖日道与月道相交有二，若正会於交，则月体全障日体，人间暗甚，谓之食既。 若同经而在交之前后者，亦见其食，但正交则食分多，交远则食分少。 日月之行，迟速不同，须突参差，离交而光生矣。 夫月食於望者，日月对躔为望，平分黄道之半。 黄道有二交，若不当二交，前后而望，则不食。 若望在二交前后者，月必食。 其食分多少，当以距交远近而推。 是时月在天，日在地之下，又非十曜之星所能食。 而月何以无光？ 盖缘月虽映日而明，若在二交限内，对经而又对纬，至甚的切，所受日光伤於大盛，以致月反无而黑，为其阳极反亢故也。 是为月蚀。 今授时历，望在交之前后，距交十三度，余则不食。 若在此限之内，则有蚀矣。 故古人以日体对充之处，名日暗虚。 似乎日之像影，月体因之失明，故云暗日，非有像影也。 强立其名，故云虚言，其非实有也。 若日月交朔於夜，对望於昼者，皆有食，但已入地而人间所不见此谓日月失昏也。 亦当修齐行香诵经。 夫日阳月阴，阳主德，阴主刑。 而有国有家者，日食则惧德之不修，月食则惧刑之有失；
chunks.translated_text:
When the stellar lodges fall into disarray and the sun and moon lose their proper times of dusk and dawn, the ancients, gazing up at the celestial patterns, observed that the rising and setting of the stars at dawn and dusk gradually diverged from their usual courses. They likened the celestial sphere to a round melon, which, having twelve segments, divides the circumference of the heavens—365¼ degrees—into twelve equal parts. Each segment thus spans thirty degrees, forty-three minutes, and seventy-five seconds. Every degree converges like spokes toward the north and south celestial poles, narrowing as it approaches the two ends, with the broadest span at the melon’s equatorial belt. This equatorial belt is called the Celestial Equator. Degrees along the Celestial Equator measure a full degree in width, but as one moves farther from the equator, the degrees grow progressively narrower, though they retain the name of a degree, they no longer span the full width of the equatorial belt. Each degree is reckoned by the distance stars of the twenty-eight lodges, forming what is called celestial longitude. Longitude divides east and west, while latitude divides north and south, both measured by their proximity to the two poles. The distance between the two poles is 182 degrees, 62 minutes, and 50 seconds. The Celestial Equator, running horizontally, lies equidistant from both poles at 91 degrees, 31 minutes, and 25 seconds. The zenith is called Songgao. The north celestial pole deviates 55 degrees and some minutes north of Songgao, while the south celestial pole, though hidden beneath the earth’s center, also deviates 55 degrees and some minutes to the south. The Celestial Equator tilts 36 degrees south of Songgao, with its sides aligning with the due east and west positions.

The sun, moon, and stellar lodges are not fixed to the heavens but instead traverse the void by virtue of the transformative qi of the great Dao, much as fish do not cling to the earth but swim through rivers by virtue of water. During the Northern Qi dynasty, Zhang Zixin observed the heavens for many years and discerned that the Five Planets exhibit cycles of advance and retreat. He thus adjusted the standard calculations to determine their daily positions. The Five Planets do not follow the Yellow Road nor the moon’s Nine Paths but instead move within and beyond the Yellow Road. Each of the Five Planets has its own course, and their speed varies with their distance from the sun, much as a traveler’s pace fluctuates with fatigue. They are also subject to additional variations, like the twists and turns of a road. The greatest deviation for Jupiter is over seven degrees; for Mars, over twenty-five degrees; for Saturn, over eight degrees; for Venus, over four degrees; and for Mercury, over six degrees. The paths of Luo, Ji, and the comet-like Bo do not vary in speed. Luo and Ji follow the moon, intersecting the Yellow Road to determine the beginnings and endings of lunar nodes. Between these intersections, Luo and Ji each move retrograde by one degree, forty-six minutes, and thirty seconds. The comet-like Bo follows the moon’s cycles of waxing and waning. The Purple Qi arises from the intercalary method: over twenty-eight years with ten intercalary months, the Purple Qi completes a circuit of the twelve celestial palaces. The Purple Qi is the Auspicious Star. Historical annotations describe it as resembling a half-moon, appearing only when a ruler possesses virtue and sagely wisdom.

The stationary segments of the stars complete one revolution around the earth each day, moving in tandem with the heavens by one degree. Those that move swiftly appear slow in comparison, while those that move slowly appear swift; those that retreat appear exceedingly swift. When their motion falls short of the heavens’ pace, the degrees they traverse mark the conjunction of the sun and moon at the same celestial longitude. A solar eclipse occurs at the new moon when the sun and moon share the same longitude but not the same latitude, resulting in conjunction without eclipse. If, however, the moon crosses the sun’s Yellow Road at the same longitude, and both share latitude, then conjunction brings an eclipse. Some claim that all ten luminaries can eclipse the sun, but this is incorrect. The sun itself is never consumed; it is merely obscured for a time by the moon’s dark body, leading the world to call it an eclipse, though the sun suffers no harm. The extent of the obscuration depends on the two points where the sun’s and moon’s paths intersect. If they meet precisely at an intersection, the moon’s body fully covers the sun’s, plunging the world into deep darkness—this is called a total eclipse. If they share longitude but are before or after the intersection, an eclipse is still visible, though the closer to the intersection, the greater the eclipse, and the farther, the lesser.

The sun and moon move at different speeds, sometimes converging, sometimes diverging; as they depart from the intersection, light is restored. A lunar eclipse occurs at the full moon when the sun and moon are in opposition, dividing the Yellow Road in half. The Yellow Road has two intersections; if the full moon does not occur at either, no eclipse takes place. If the full moon is near the intersections, the moon will eclipse. The extent of the eclipse is determined by its proximity to the intersection. At this time, the moon is in the sky while the sun is beneath the earth, and no other luminary can eclipse it. Yet why does the moon lose its light? Though the moon reflects the sun’s brilliance, when it lies within the bounds of the two intersections, directly opposite the sun in both longitude and latitude, the intensity of the sunlight overwhelms it, causing the moon to darken—an excess of yang leading to its own reversal. This is a lunar eclipse. According to the *Shoushi* calendar, if the full moon occurs within thirteen degrees of an intersection, an eclipse will not occur; beyond this limit, an eclipse takes place.

Thus, the ancients named the region opposite the sun’s illumination the "dark void," as if it were the sun’s shadow, causing the moon to lose its light—though no such shadow exists. The term is a forced designation, hence called "void," for it is not truly substantial. If the sun and moon conjoin at night or oppose each other during the day, eclipses may occur, but if they have already set beneath the earth, they remain unseen—this is what is meant by the sun and moon losing their proper times of dusk and dawn. In such cases, one should likewise perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite scriptures.

The sun is yang, the moon is yin; yang governs virtue, yin governs punishment. Those who rule states and households fear, when the sun eclipses, that virtue has not been cultivated, and when the moon eclipses, that punishment has been misapplied.

chunks.original_text: 故日食修德，月食修刑，亦当修斋诵经，以禳救之。 所谓救者，观乎天文以察时变，预为之儆戒耳。 四时失度，阴阳不调。 以世法释，自古以分至为春，夏、秋、冬四时之中，而四时以冬至为首者，阳道也。 古历立元纪蔀步口切。 章，年月日时，各有其事。 时者，太阳所历地盘十二方位； 日者，太阳出没一周； 月者，太阴盈亏始终； 年者，寒暑荣枯一变； 章者，至朔合於一时； 蔀者，至朔合於子时； 纪者，至朔合於甲子日子时； 元者，至朔合於甲子岁甲子日甲子时也。 百芒为毫，百毫为杪，百杪为分，分即刻也。 二十五刻为三时，十二时为日，三十日为月，十二月为年，十九年为一章，四章为一蔀，二十蔀为一纪，三纪为一元，则一元是四千五百六十年。 一元之首，冬至太阳在子，一元满则冬至太阳在卯，二元满则冬至太阳反缠午，三元满冬至太阳在酉，四元满冬至太阳复躔子。 则四元乃一万八干二百四十年。 太阳还元而积六千七百二十闰者，盖一章有七闰也。 四时失度，阴阳不调者，春则国有恐，民多疫； 夏则禾不熟，女有灾； 秋则民虐而致齀渠牛切。 嚏； 丁计切。 冬则多疠而来痼疾； 皆阴阳不调之所致。 亦当修斋诵经，以召天地之和气也。 国主有灾，兵革四兴。 夫天下太平，国阜民安，是一人有庆，兆民赖之也。 若国家多事，兵役迭起，为臣子者，当尽忠效力以报上也。 师之与友，恩不可忘。 夫斋戒诵经，功德甚重。 斋者，清心； 戒者，绝境。 若有经而无戒，犹有鱼而无荃。 昔老君五戒授尹真人，一百八十戒授于真人； 天师七十二戒，太清二十四戒，修真十戒，九真妙戒，灵宝九戒，正一五戒。 其他载经忏者多，然皆以戒欲为首。 故老君曰：若能全戒於内，和光於外，庶几灵摽之崖矣。 欲心尽净，方可成功，则生死受赖，其福难胜也。 颂曰：度人功大果无边，句句分明好结缘。 元始劫来师与友，如今都会大罗天。 道言：凡有是经，能为天地帝主兆民行是功德，有灾之日，发心修斋，烧香诵经十过，皆诸天记名，万神侍卫，右别至人，克得为圣君金阙之臣。 诸天记人功过，毫分无失。 天中魔王亦保举尔身，得道者乃当洞明至言也。 上阳子曰：凡有是经。 盖经者，道也。 凡有道之士，与天地合德，与日月合明，与造化同体。 若为国、为家、为人为己，行此经中之功德，诸天皆与记名，万神为之侍卫。 右别至人。 至人，乃有功勤者，为圣君金阙之臣。 如天师旌阳、浮丘真君之道备德隆，而皆为金阙之臣也。 ．修学之士见善勇为，有过即改，改过则神明阴卫，积善则功德尊高。 诸天记人功过，并无遣失。 傥功高德重，天中魔王亦行保举。 得道者，闻道之人。 须当洞明经旨，有成仙之至言也。 颂曰：凡有是经便炼丹，丹成克得步玄阑。 三千功行浑余事，金阙官宫礼玉颜。 诸天中大梵隐语无量音 《天公经》云：大罗天宫有《灵书上篇》，广生高映是也。 又有龙章凤篆，正文观觉郁褴是也。 又有《灵书中篇》，亶娄阿苍是也。 经谓虽有诸天，犹拘劫运，於是玉宸道君撰《元始灵书》三篇，凝云作篆，每字方广一丈，八角垂芒，以镇三十二天。 即如上三篇皆道君所迷，天真皇人所书也。

Thus, when the sun eclipses, cultivate virtue; when the moon eclipses, rectify punishment—yet one should also perform purification rites, recite scriptures, and offer prayers to avert calamity. What is meant by "averting" is to observe celestial patterns, discern temporal anomalies, and take precautionary measures in advance. When the four seasons lose their proper measure and yin and yang fall out of harmony—

Interpreting this through worldly principles: since antiquity, the solstices and equinoxes have marked the divisions of spring, summer, autumn, and winter, with winter solstice as the head of the four seasons, for it is the Way of yang. Ancient calendars established the *yuan*, *ji*, *bu*, *zhang*, and precise calculations. The *zhang* governs the harmonization of years, months, days, and hours, each with its own function. The *hours* are the twelve earthly positions traversed by the sun; the *day* is one full cycle of the sun’s rising and setting; the *month* is the waxing and waning of the moon from beginning to end; the *year* is one cycle of cold and heat, flourishing and withering; the *zhang* is the conjunction of solstice and new moon in a single hour; the *bu* is their conjunction at the *zi* hour; the *ji* is their conjunction on a *jiazi* day at the *zi* hour; the *yuan* is their conjunction in a *jiazi* year, on a *jiazi* day, at the *jiazi* hour. One hundred *mang* make a *hao*, one hundred *hao* make a *miao*, one hundred *miao* make a *fen* (a *ke*). Twenty-five *ke* make three hours, twelve hours make a day, thirty days make a month, twelve months make a year, nineteen years make one *zhang*, four *zhang* make one *bu*, twenty *bu* make one *ji*, and three *ji* make one *yuan*—thus one *yuan* spans four thousand five hundred and sixty years. At the beginning of a *yuan*, the winter solstice sun resides in *zi*; when the *yuan* is complete, the winter solstice sun moves to *mao*; when two *yuan* are complete, the winter solstice sun returns to *wu*; when three *yuan* are complete, the winter solstice sun resides in *you*; and when four *yuan* are complete, the winter solstice sun returns to *zi*—thus four *yuan* comprise eighteen thousand two hundred and forty years. The sun’s return to its origin accumulates six thousand seven hundred and twenty intercalary months, for each *zhang* contains seven intercalary months.

When the four seasons lose their proper measure and yin and yang fall out of harmony: in spring, the state is beset by fear and the people suffer epidemics; in summer, crops fail to ripen and women endure misfortune; in autumn, the people grow cruel and suffer from *è* (sneezing) and *tì* (hiccups); in winter, plagues abound and chronic illnesses arise—all these are the result of yin and yang falling out of harmony. One should likewise perform purification rites and recite scriptures to summon the harmonious qi of Heaven and Earth.

When the ruler of a state faces calamity and warfare erupts on all sides, if the realm enjoys great peace, the state prospers and the people live in security—this is the blessing of one man, upon which the multitudes depend. But if the state is beset by turmoil and military campaigns arise in succession, ministers and subjects must devote their loyalty and efforts to repay their sovereign.

Teachers and friends—one must never forget their kindness. The merit of purification rites and scripture recitation is profound. *Zhai* (purification) is the cleansing of the heart; *jie* (precepts) is the severance from worldly attachments. To have scriptures without precepts is like having fish without a fishing line.

In ancient times, Lord Lao transmitted the Five Precepts to Master Yin, and the One Hundred and Eighty Precepts to the Perfected One. The Celestial Master’s Seventy-Two Precepts, the Supreme Clarity’s Twenty-Four Precepts, the Ten Precepts for Cultivating the Real, the Nine Wondrous Precepts of the Nine Perfected, the Nine Precepts of the Numinous Treasure, and the Orthodox One’s Five Precepts—though many are recorded in scriptures and repentance texts, all place the restraint of desire at their head. Thus Lord Lao said: "If one can fully uphold the precepts within and harmonize one’s light without, one may approach the precipice of spiritual transcendence. Only when desire is utterly purified can success be achieved—then one’s blessings in life and death will be boundless."

The ode says:
The merit of delivering beings is vast, its fruits boundless,
Each phrase distinct, fostering good affinity.
From the kalpas of the Primordial Beginning, teachers and friends,
Now gather in the Great Canopy Heaven.

The Dao states: Whoever possesses this scripture and performs these meritorious deeds for the rulers of Heaven and Earth and the multitudes of people—on days of calamity, if one resolves to perform purification rites, burn incense, and recite the scripture ten times—all the heavens will record their names, the myriad spirits will attend and protect them, and those of exceptional attainment will become ministers of the Golden Gates of the Sage Sovereign. The heavens record the merits and transgressions of people with flawless precision. Even the Demon Kings of Heaven will vouch for such a one, and those who attain the Dao will thoroughly comprehend the ultimate teachings.

Master Shangyang said: Whoever possesses this scripture—*jing* (scripture) is the Dao. All those who embody the Dao align their virtue with Heaven and Earth, their brightness with the sun and moon, and their essence with the workings of creation. Whether for state, household, others, or oneself, performing the meritorious deeds within this scripture will cause all the heavens to record their names, and the myriad spirits to attend and protect them. Those of exceptional attainment—those who have accumulated merit and diligence—will become ministers of the Golden Gates of the Sage Sovereign. Such as the Celestial Master Zhengyang and the Perfected Lord Fuqiu, whose Dao was complete and virtue lofty, both became ministers of the Golden Gates.

Students of cultivation should act with courage upon encountering goodness, and correct their faults upon recognizing them. Correcting faults ensures the unseen protection of the divine, while accumulating goodness elevates one’s merit and virtue. The heavens record the merits and transgressions of people without omission. If one’s merit is great and virtue profound, even the Demon Kings of Heaven will vouch for them. Those who attain the Dao are those who have heard the Dao—they must thoroughly comprehend the scripture’s essence to achieve the ultimate teachings of immortality.

The ode says:
Whoever possesses this scripture refines the elixir,
Upon its completion, they ascend the mysterious threshold.
Three thousand merits and deeds are but secondary,
In the Golden Gates’ halls, they bow before the Jade Countenance.

Among the Great Brahma Hidden Words of the Myriad Sounds in the Heavens, *The Scripture of the Heavenly Duke* states: In the Palace of the Great Canopy Heaven, there is *The Numinous Writ of the Upper Chapter*, known as *Guangsheng Gaoying*. There are also the Dragon Script and Phoenix Seal, known as *Zhengwen Guanjue Yulan*. And there is *The Numinous Writ of the Middle Chapter*, known as *Danlou Acang*. Though the scriptures speak of the many heavens, they are still bound by kalpas. Thus the Jade Clarity Dao Lord composed *The Three Chapters of the Primordial Beginning’s Numinous Writ*, inscribing them in coagulated clouds, each character a *zhang* in width and height, with eight-pointed rays, to stabilize the Thirty-Two Heavens. The three chapters mentioned above were all transmitted by the Dao Lord and transcribed by the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign.

chunks.original_text: 后天真皇人美此隐音，重述《灵书下篇》，森角储云是也。 如此乃有四篇。 今人止谓中篇而不诵上下篇者，岂上天秘惜，而下世罕闻之乎？ 《内音经》云：元始天尊於赤明世界栢陵说法，众真侍座，云雾郁勃，三日三夜，玄阴不解。 五老上帝白天尊言：天尊演教，所未曾见，今白日昼阴，不审何故？ 天尊曰：乃诸天发瑞，灵应自然，玉字焕烂，障蔽天光。 咸令四座暝目伏听； 俄顷，天炁顿启，冥暗豁消。 忽有灵书，字方一丈，见於空玄之上。 天尊普告四座； 夫此灵书八会？ 其趣宛奥，难可寻详。 当命天真皇人训释其音，以教诸天应得道成真有仙名者。 天真皇人奉天尊明命，初启《灵书上篇》，但见广生高映，文彩灿烂，莫可窥睹。 次启《龙篆正文》，又见观觉郁褴，字皆八角垂芒，精光夺目。 复启《灵书中篇》，始见亶娄阿苍，字方一丈，金光洞映。 尔时天真皇人大兴悲叹，不敢议问。 良久言曰：《灵书上篇》，龙篆正文，天宫所秘，劫运未周，大道之奥，未当闻于下世。 伏惟《灵书中篇》，仰感天尊大慈，三五应期，真道宜行，乃释灵音，下教於未闻也。 是以上篇及于龙篆，未敢轻泄玄秘，唯中篇略仿天真皇人之训，旁加增灭，使万世之下，得闻经之隐奥也。 他本以《灵书上篇》及龙篆正文置下篇之后者，非是。 今正之 元始灵书上篇　道君撰
chunks.translated_text:
Later, the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign, admiring these recondite sounds, further expounded *The Numinous Writ of the Lower Chapter*, known as *Senjiao Chuyun*. Thus there came to be four chapters. Yet today, people speak only of the Middle Chapter and recite neither the Upper nor the Lower—could it be that the heavens guard their secrets jealously, so that the lower world seldom hears of them?

*The Scripture of Inner Sound* states: The Primordial Celestial Honored One preached the Dao in the Red Clarity World at Cypress Mound, with the assembled Perfected in attendance. Clouds and mists surged thickly for three days and nights, and the dark *yin* did not disperse. The Five Elder Thearchs addressed the Celestial Honored One, saying: "Never before have we witnessed the Celestial Honored One expound the teachings. Yet now, in broad daylight, darkness prevails—what is the reason?" The Celestial Honored One replied: "This is the auspicious response of the many heavens, a numinous manifestation of the natural Way. The jade characters blaze with radiance, obscuring the light of heaven." He commanded all present to close their eyes and listen reverently. In an instant, the celestial *qi* suddenly parted, and the gloom vanished. Suddenly, a numinous writ appeared in the void above, each character a *zhang* in width and height. The Celestial Honored One proclaimed to the assembly: "This Numinous Writ of the Eight Convergences—its purport is profound and abstruse, difficult to fathom in detail. I shall command the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign to interpret its sounds, so as to instruct those among the many heavens who are destined to attain the Dao, achieve Perfection, and bear the name of immortals."

The Heavenly Perfected Sovereign, obeying the luminous command of the Celestial Honored One, first unsealed *The Numinous Writ of the Upper Chapter*. He beheld only *Guangsheng Gaoying*, its literary splendor dazzling, beyond all scrutiny. Next, he unsealed *The Dragon Script of the Orthodox Text* and saw *Zhengwen Guanjue Yulan*, each character eight-pointed with trailing rays, their luminous essence overwhelming the eye. Then he unsealed *The Numinous Writ of the Middle Chapter* and at last beheld *Danlou Acang*, each character a *zhang* in width, its golden light penetrating and radiant.

At that time, the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign sighed deeply with sorrow and dared not venture questions. After a long while, he said: "*The Numinous Writ of the Upper Chapter* and *The Dragon Script of the Orthodox Text* are secrets of the celestial palaces. The kalpas have not yet run their course, and the mysteries of the Great Dao ought not to be heard in the lower world. Yet in *The Numinous Writ of the Middle Chapter*, I humbly perceive the great compassion of the Celestial Honored One. The Three and Five have met their destined time, and the True Dao should now be practiced. Thus he revealed the numinous sounds, imparting teachings to those who have not yet heard. Therefore, the Upper Chapter and the Dragon Script must not be lightly disclosed as profound secrets. Only the Middle Chapter, following the interpretations of the Heavenly Perfected Sovereign and with minor additions and omissions, allows those in later ages to glimpse the hidden mysteries of the scripture."

Other versions place *The Numinous Writ of the Upper Chapter* and *The Dragon Script of the Orthodox Text* after the Lower Chapter—this is incorrect. Here it is corrected:

*The Numinous Writ of the Upper Chapter of the Primordial Beginning* — composed by the Dao Lord.
